As we reported in March, Google is working on a new way to discover apps and games for Chromebooks in a project it\u0026#8217;s dubbed \u0026#8220;App Mall.\u0026#8221; Details were scant at the time, but we predicted that it would serve as a unified home for apps built for the web, Android, Linux, and more. This afternoon, the folks at Chrome Unboxed spotted that the new feature is available on ChromeOS today if you enable a special flag (shared at the bottom of this post). However, Google built the ChromeOS App Mall as a traditional web app, meaning you can try it for yourself on any device. Currently, the storefront is divided into three main sections \u2013 Home, Apps, and Games \u2013 as well as a search function. On the homepage, you\u0026#8217;ll find two lists of featured apps and games, below which are two collections of blog-like \u0026#8220;spotlights\u0026#8221; on particular apps and games. Notably, only web and Android apps currently appear in the App Mall, though we hope this could change in the future. If all of this looks and sounds familiar, it\u0026#8217;s because it\u0026#8217;s almost identical to the existing functionality of ChromeOS\u0026#8217;s built-in Explore app. This includes the same set of apps and spotlights, right down to the same web/PWA installation dialog. For now, the main differences are in the inclusion of an \u0026#8220;Experiment\u0026#8221; label in the bottom left and a shortcut to the Play Store in the side menu. That being the case, we\u0026#8217;ll need to keep an eye on the App Mall over the coming months to see how Google differentiates it from Explore. Chrome Unboxed notes that with the associated flag enabled, the App Mall automatically appears as a dedicated shortcut pinned to the app shelf. There were no major surprises to the actual iPad announcements, as they were very much in line with what we\u0026#8217;d been expecting \u0026#8230; iPad Pro We did, as expected, get a new iPad Pro with tandem OLED display, in both 11-inch and 13-inch versions. The display is of course the headline news. The Ultra Retina XDR display features state-of-the-art tandem OLED technology that uses two OLED panels and combines the light from both to provide phenomenal full-screen brightness. The new iPad Pro supports an incredible 1000 nits of full-screen brightness for SDR and HDR content, and 1600 nits peak for HDR. No other device of its kind delivers this level of extreme dynamic range. Tandem OLED technology enables sub-millisecond control over the color and luminance of each pixel, taking XDR precision further than ever. One very pleasant surprise here was the option of matte glass (what Apple calls nano-texture glass). This is a $100 upgrade, but it\u0026#8217;s still a very good option to have available. Both models did indeed get the new M4 chip \u2013 something which even the source of the rumor, Bloomberg\u0026#8217;s Mark Gurman, didn\u0026#8217;t dare describe as anything more definite than a possibility. M4 builds on the GPU architecture of M3 \u2014 the 10-core GPU includes powerful features like Dynamic Caching, and hardware-accelerated mesh shading and ray tracing, which come to iPad for the first time. Coupled with higher unified memory bandwidth, pro rendering apps like Octane will see up to 4x faster performance than M2. A new advanced Media Engine includes support for AV1 decode, providing more power-efficient playback of high-resolution video experiences from streaming services. My view for some time has been that fewer and fewer people actually need the power of the iPad Pro, and that\u0026#8217;s even more true of this model, but it\u0026#8217;s still insane how much performance Apple has squeezed into an iPad. Speaking of squeezing, the new iPad Pro is also thinner than ever \u2013 so much so that a Thunderbolt cable actually protrudes above the display! Verdict: A truly incredible achievement, but one which very few people need. The starting price also got bumped up. The cost of maxing out the 13-inch iPad Pro, together with the new Magic Keyboard and Apple Pencil Pro, now exceeds $2,700. That\u0026#8217;s more than the cost of most MacBook Pro configurations. iPad Air The new iPad Air also aligned with pre-event reporting. The big news here, of course, is the 13-inch model. For the first time, iPad buyers are no longer forced to pay for Pro features they don\u0026#8217;t need just to get a bigger screen. The 11-inch model is a relatively modest update, but also remains at the same $599 starting price, so no complaints there. There\u0026#8217;s little reason for anyone who has the previous model to upgrade, though it is good to see the front-facing camera repositioned for use in landscape orientation. Verdict: The addition of a 13-inch iPad Air is a truly fantastic addition to the iPad line-up, and helps to offset the increasingly eye-watering pricing of the Pro models. For $799, you\u0026#8217;re still getting a fantastic display even without the OLED upgrade of the Pro, and this screen size is a real joy for immersive content, as well as multi-window working. \u0026#8216;New\u0026#8217; entry-level iPad There was no new entry-level iPad as such, but Apple did drop the 9th-gen model from the line-up, and give the 10th-gen one a very welcome $100 price cut. That effectively means that the cost of entry to iPad got a slight increase to $349, but it\u0026#8217;s much better value. Verdict: This is great news, and I view it as almost as good a move as a brand new device. Magic Keyboard The new Magic Keyboard was a smaller upgrade than some reports had suggested, but the aluminum base does give it a more premium look, and it\u0026#8217;s good to see that Apple hasn\u0026#8217;t increased the price even further. The key benefits here are the function keys and larger trackpad. The bad news is that it\u0026#8217;s only compatible with the latest models (though this does include the Air, which is a nice surprise). That means that anyone who wants to take advantage of it can do so only by replacing their iPad. Verdict: A worthwhile upgrade, without a bump in price, but no backward compatibility is disappointing. Had it been iPad Pro only, that might have been more understandable given the ultra-thin design, but it\u0026#8217;s less forgivable given that it can accommodate both the new 0.2-inch thick iPad Pro 6th generation and the 0.24-inch thick iPad Air, yet not the 0.25-inch thick 5th-gen iPad Pro. Apple Pencil Pro The new Apple Pencil Pro didn\u0026#8217;t get all of the new features rumored. There are no magnetically-attached interchangeable tips, and no specific eraser feature. However, it did deliver some of the other upgrades were were expecting: the squeeze gesture and Find My support. It also gets a new Barrel Roll gesture, which may have been the source of some of the interchangeable tips confusion, as this does provide a means of switching between thinner and thicker brushes, for example. Verdict: Some worthwhile new features for sure, and the good news is no price increase over the 2nd-gen. However, it\u0026#8217;s again disappointing that there\u0026#8217;s no backward compatibility with previous iPad Pro models. Relocating the front camera \u2013 with corresponding changes to the magnetic attachment and charging \u2013 is the likely problem here. I doubt it was deliberate: Apple would likely have loved to sell a new Pencil to owners of older models. Final Cut Pro and Logic Pro Some very welcome improvements here! Live Multicam capabilities in the iPad version of FCP is a phenomenal achievement, as is stem-splitting and additional AI musicians in Logic Pro. Most exciting of all is the announcement of a new Final Cut Camera app coming soon. Bad news for Filmic and BlackMagic, whose apps will likely be Sherlocked, but probably good news for iPhone and iPad owners. Verdict: All welcome surprises here! All in, then, a very solid event. 9to5Mac Skip to main content Toggle main menu 9to5Mac Logo Go to the 9to5Mac home page Switch site 9to5Toys 9to5Google Logo9to5Google Electrek Drone DJ LogoDroneDJ Space Explored About Privacy Toggle social menu Toggle dark mode Search for: Submit Toggle search form Exclusives Store Podcasts Apple@Work Happy Hour 9to5Mac Daily Vision Vision Pro visionOS Hands-on iPhone iPhone iPhone 14 iPhone 15 iPhone 16 iOS 17 Mac Mac MacBook Pro MacBook Air iMac Mac mini Mac Studio Mac Pro macOS Sonoma Watch Apple Watch Apple Watch Ultra Apple Health Apple Watch SE Apple Watch Series 9 watchOS 10 iPad iPad Pro iPad Air iPad mini iPad iPadOS iPadOS 17 Music and TV Apple Music AirPods HomePod Apple TV tvOS 17 Guides Reviews How Tos AAPL Apple Store Apple Arcade Apple Card Apple Silicon Apple One Apple Fitness\u002B CarPlay Siri HomeKit Toggle dark mode TV Amazon Prime Video More ads coming to Prime Video, including interactive shopping ads during pauses Ryan Christoffel\u0026nbsp;|\u0026nbsp;May 8 2024 - 6:39 am PT 16 Comments 2024 is shaping up to be the year of ads for Amazon Prime Video. In January the streaming service, which has long been ad-free, debuted an ad-based tier and instantly moved nearly all its users into that tier. Since then, the only way for Prime subscribers to avoid ads has been to pay an extra $3 per month. Pretty soon, that $3 option may be more compelling as Prime Video is planning to increase the number of ways users will see ads and make shopping a key component of those ads. Prime Video to increase ads and promote shopping From Scharon Harding at Ars Technica: Those who opted for Prime Video with commercials will soon see shoppable carousel ads, interactive pause ads, and interactive brand trivia ads, as Amazon calls them. Amazon said that advertisers could buy these new displays to be shown \u0026#8220;across the vast majority of content on Prime Video, wherever it\u2019s streamed.\u0026#8221; All the new ad formats allow a viewer to place advertised products in their Amazon cart. Here\u2019s what each of the three ad changes will bring: Carousel ads will play during the normal ad breaks, providing a variety of suggested items to shop for and the option to add them directly to your Amazon cart. Pause ads are a new addition, bringing advertising to the pause screen for featured products which will also include an \u2018Add to cart\u2019 button. Brand trivia ads will seek to promote ad engagement by offering incentives like Amazon shopping credits. 9to5Mac\u2019s Take Making ads more interactive to promote shopping was a natural next step for the e-commerce juggernaut. Ad-based tiers have become a norm for nearly every streaming service. But at a time when competition among streamers is so strong, it still feels like a lot of not-so-great change for Prime Video users in a short span of time. Apple TV\u002B is the one major streaming player still holding on to its ad-free approach. As more moves like this happen, though, it will be interesting to see how much longer that approach lasts. Where to watch the showYou should see the meteors low in the sky if you look to the east before dawn. There is now so much clean power that global fossil fuel power generation is about to fall, along with its emissions. Victoria Seabrook Climate reporter @SeabrookClimate Wednesday 8 May 2024 01:00, UK Image: China added half the world\u0026#x27;s new solar in 2023. Pic: AP Why you can trust Sky News Experts have hailed a \u0022critical turning point\u0022 as renewable power generated a record-breaking 30% of the world\u0027s electricity last year, new data has found.It raises hopes that the peaking of global greenhouse gas emissions is on the horizon. But there are concerns many countries are being held up in their switch to clean power because they cannot access the cash needed to fund it.Last year\u0027s renewable power \u0022milestone\u0022 was driven by yet another booming year for wind and especially solar.China, Brazil and the Netherlands led the way in terms of fast roll-outs, thinktank Ember said in its annual Global Electricity Review. China alone accounted for 51% of new solar generation and 60% of new wind, even as it continued to build vast amounts of new coal power too.Christiana Figueres, former United Nations climate chief, called 2023 a \u0022critical turning point\u0022. More on Energy UK greenhouse emissions fall as high energy bills see homes cut back on electricity Former cost-of-living tsar Buttress to run Ovo Energy Nearly four million smart meters are faulty, figures show Related Topics: Energyclimate changerenewable energy She said \u0022outdated\u0022 fossil fuels now can\u0027t compete with the \u0022exponential innovations and declining cost curves in renewable energy and storage\u0022.\u0022All of humanity and the planet upon which we depend will be better off for it,\u0022 she added. Advertisement In the last two decades, solar and wind have defied expectations and grown far faster than expected, surging from just 0.2% of global power generation in 2000 to 13.4% in 2023.Dave Jones, Ember\u0027s head of global insights, said the huge growth was due to \u0022matured\u0022 policies and technologies and a plummet in costs.The cost of solar power halved last year despite a surge in demand, thanks to an explosion in manufacturing capacity.Meanwhile problems that had held up wind power - such as inflationary costs - began to resolve, unlocking more projects. Please use Chrome browser for a more accessible video player 2:18 China ramps up coal power despite pledge to control it A \u0027genuinely ambitious\u0027 renewables targetAt the COP28 climate summit in Dubai last year leaders pledged to triple renewable power capacity by 2030.The \u0022genuinely ambitious\u0022 target shows leaders are backing renewables, which are the \u0022main tools that we have in the box today to deliver the big emissions reductions we need\u0022, rather than riskier technology, such as that to remove carbon dioxide from the atmosphere, Mr Jones said.Ember suggests the global burning of fossil fuels in the power sector probably peaked in 2023 and will start to fall this year, along with the pollution and emissions they bring.As the power sector accounts for the largest share of global emissions, that means global emissions could start to fall soon too.That is good news for curbing climate change, although scientists have repeatedly warned that emissions are not falling fast enough to limit global warming to agreed safer levels.Mr Jones said the pace of emissions falls \u0022depends on how fast the renewables revolution continues\u0022.Joab Okanda, a senior adviser for Christian Aid, based in Kenya, said the roll-out would be \u0022so much faster with the right investment\u0022 in African nations, which often face much higher borrowing costs than other countries. The fundraiser\u2019s dress code this year was \u201CThe Garden of Time,\u201D which led to many botanical interpretations from a bevy of celebrities, including musicians, actors, and designers.The 2024 Costume Institute Benefit celebrates the Costume Institute\u2019s new exhibition, \u201CSleeping Beauties: Reawakening Fashion,\u201D which includes 250 garments and accessories spanning four centuries in order to \u201Cexamine the cyclical themes of rebirth and renewal,\u201D per the museum. Guests at the Met Gala this year included Ariana Grande, Awkwafina, Aya Nakamura, Cardi B, Charli XCX, Doja Cat, Donald Glover (aka Childish Gambino), Dua Lipa, Ed Sheeran, Erykah Badu, FKA twigs, Jack Harlow, Janelle Mon\u00E1e, Blackpink\u2019s Jennie, Jon Batiste, Karol G, Kylie Minogue, Lana Del Rey, Leon Bridges, Lil Nas X, Little Simz, Lizzo, Omar Apollo, Rauw Alejandro, Sabrina Carpenter, Sam Smith, Shakira, Troye Sivan, Tyla, and many more.Bad Bunny, Jennifer Lopez, Zendaya, and Chris Hemsworth joined Vogue editor-in-chief Anna Wintour as co-chairs for this year\u2019s gala. Ad ChoicesCN Entertainment","RSSSummary":"The pop star was introduced by Troye Sivan and Jerry Seinfeld, respectively, before each song","PublishDate":"2024-05-05T22:48:25","IsHeadline":false,"IsPaywall":false,"Summary":"Summary Unavailable.","ImageURL":"https://media.pitchfork.com/photos/6638e3e207880726f359271c/16:9/w_1280,c_limit/Dua-Lipa.jpg","PublisherID":25,"Business":false,"CompaniesMentioned":"","HasJakeFlag":false},{"Title":"TechCrunch Minute: When did iPads get as expensive as MacBooks?","Url":"https://techcrunch.com/2024/05/08/techcrunch-minute-when-did-ipads-get-as-expensive-as-macbooks/","Text":" Watch: When did iPads get as expensive as MacBooks? | TechCrunch Login SearchStartupsVentureSecurityAICryptoAppsEventsStartup BattlefieldMoreFintechHardwareTransportationMedia \u0026amp; EntertainmentNewslettersPodcastsPartner ContentCrunchboard JobsContact UsSearch Hardware TechCrunch Minute: When did iPads get as expensive as MacBooks? Alex Wilhelm 8:45 AM PDT \u2022 May 8, 2024 Comment Apple\u2019s iPad event had a lot to like. New iPads with new chips and new sizes, a new Apple Pencil, and even some software updates. If you are a big fan of Apple hardware, well, it was probably a good day. Now you can get an updated and thinner iPad Pro, if that\u2019s your jam. But while watching the event and parsing its news in the immediate aftermath I ran into a personal sticking point. While it\u2019s welcome that iPads are getting more and more powerful, their price point is challenging and even surpassing those of many computers. Which seems a little bit backwards. Here\u2019s how TechCrunch reported on the matter: It\u2019s also an expensive machine: The iPad Pro starts at $999 for the 11-inch model. The 13-inch version costs $1,299. And the iPad Pro doesn\u2019t come with a keyboard or a pencil in the box, so you often end up paying more than the price of a MacBook Air. Those prices go up by $200 if you want cellular connectivity. So if you wanted a new iPad Pro 13-inch with cellular connectivity and a keyboard you are well in excess of the base price for a Macbook Pro. You know, a full real computer with no caveats. The thing here is that Apple\u2019s chips are great, and its laptops are super lovely. I am writing to you on an M-based MacBook Pro right now, and it\u2019s gosh darn lovely. I just cannot imagine paying a similar ticket price for something that is, well, not as good as a productivity device and has a more locked-down OS to boot. I could be completely bonkers here, but the pricing and positioning for Apple\u2019s impressive new devices leaves me puzzled. Let\u2019s talk about it. Messi\u2019s First Soccer Contract, Written on a Napkin, Is Up for Auction","Url":"https://theathletic.com/5241184/2024/05/08/lionel-messi-barcelona-napkin-auction/","Text":"Lionel Messi\u2019s first SportsNWSLNCAAFNCAAMMen\u0026#x27;s World CupWomen\u0026#x27;s World CupThe Athletic InkReal Madrid vs. Bayern Munich liveLionel Messi\u2019s first Barcelona contract, signed on napkin, on sale at auction By Colin Millar and Pol Ball\u00FAs3m agoThe napkin upon which Lionel Messi\u2019s first Barcelona agreement was informally written has gone on sale at auction.Bonhams \u2014 a privately owned, London-based international auction house \u2014 are running the auction until May 17, with a starting price of \u00A3220,000 ($274.55k), on behalf of Argentine player agent Horacio Gaggioli.AdvertisementThe agreement was reached on December 14, 2000, with Barcelona director Carles Rexach desperate for the club to sign Messi, then aged 13.Messi had impressed during his two-week trial with Barcelona in September 2000, but the club was initially reluctant to sign such a young, non-European player.Rexach became concerned that the Catalan club would miss out on the signing of Messi, who had returned to his home city of Rosario in Argentina.Gaggioli told The Athletic last year that he had informed Rexach in December 2000 that if they could not commit to signing Messi \u2014 the teenager would be offered to other clubs, including Real Madrid.Rexach invited Gaggioli to dinner in Barcelona to make a final decision over Messi, but there was one problem: Rexach did not have time to draw up or print out a contract but needed the relevant signatures on a document that would later become legally binding.His solution was to take a napkin and write down contractual words which would then be signed by the relevant parties, to signal a legal commitment.GO DEEPERMessi, Rosario and Newell\u0027s: The love between a superstar, his hometown and boyhood clubThe napkin read: \u201CIn Barcelona, on December 14, 2000, and in the presence of the gentleman (the agent, Josep Maria) Minguella and Horacio (Gaggioli), Carles Rexach, technical secretary of FCB, commits under his responsibility, despite the opinion of others who are against signing Lionel Messi, as long as the agreed fees are maintained.\u201DRexach signed the napkin along with football agents, Minguella \u2014 who had worked on multiple Barca deals in the past, including Diego Maradona \u2014 and Gaggioli.\u201CThis is one of the most thrilling items I have ever handled,\u201D Ian Ehling, head of fine books and manuscripts at Bonhams New York said. \u201CYes, it\u2019s a paper napkin, but it\u2019s the famous napkin that was at the inception of Lionel Messi\u2019s career.\u201CIt changed the life of Messi, the future of FC Barcelona, and was instrumental in giving some of the most glorious moments of football to billions of fans around the globe.\u201D Messi made his Barcelona debut in 2004 and scored 672 goals for the club in 778 appearances before leaving in 2021 (Lluis Gene/AFP via Getty Images)Commenting on the event years later, Gaggioli called it a \u201Cmarvellous moment\u201D.\u201CThat napkin broke the deadlock,\u201D he added.\u201CMy lawyers looked at it. The napkin had everything: my name, his name, the date. It\u2019s notarised. It was a legal document.\u201CIt\u2019ll be a part of me for the rest of my life. The napkin will always be at my side. I live in Andorra and I\u2019ve kept the napkin in a safe inside a bank.\u201DAdvertisementOn Wednesday, Minguella told Catalunya Radio that the napkin had been in his office for years and that he had offered Barcelona the chance to display it in the club\u2019s museum.He claims he did not receive a response from Barcelona and that he will now ask lawyers to discover who is the legal owner of the napkin and how anyone can prove that they legally own it to put it for sale.Minguella has insisted he does not wish to profit from the napkin, but that he would prefer to see it in Barcelona\u2019s museum or that if it is sold, for the money to go to the club\u2019s foundation.GO DEEPERLionel Messi: The evolution of the greatest footballer of all timeGO DEEPER\u0027A thuggish flamingo\u0027: Why China turned on Lionel Messi(Pascal Le Segretain/Getty Images) Get all-access to exclusive stories.Subscribe to The Athletic for in-depth coverage of your favorite players, teams, leagues and clubs. Carles Rexach desperate for the club to sign the Argentine, then 13 years old.","PublishDate":"2024-05-08T15:14:45","IsHeadline":false,"IsPaywall":false,"Summary":"Summary Unavailable.","ImageURL":"https://cdn.theathletic.com/app/uploads/2024/01/31113833/lionel-messi-balon-dor-scaled-e1706719135759.jpeg","PublisherID":3,"Business":false,"CompaniesMentioned":"","HasJakeFlag":false},{"Title":"Are There Enough Fans for the N.H.L.\u2019s Smallest Market to Keep Its Team?","Url":"https://theathletic.com/5470097/2024/05/07/winnipeg-jets-relocation-owner-threat/","Text":"Are there enough fans to keep a team in the NHL\u2019s smallest market? - The AthleticNHLTeamsScores \u0026amp; ScheduleStandingsPodcastsFantasyNHL OddsNHL PicksDraft Prospect RankingsAre there enough fans to keep a team in the NHL\u2019s smallest market? Dan RobsonMay 7, 2024WINNIPEG \u2013 Three hours before puck drop, Greg Burnett awaited the fate of his beloved Winnipeg Jets, on the brink of elimination.The 56-year-old retired high school teacher stood in a fenced-off courtyard, just beyond a statue of the late Jets legend Dale Hawerchuk, between the glittering reflection of newly developed office towers on what used to be a vast parking lot in Winnipeg\u2019s age-worn downtown.AdvertisementBurnett felt optimistic. He calls it a glass-half-full mentality when his team is \u201Cparadoxically aligned with impending doom.\u201DHe sipped a Michelob Light as hundreds of Jets fans filled the streets around Canada Life Centre ahead of Game 5 of the team\u2019s first-round playoff series against the Colorado Avalanche, trailing 3-1.The stakes that night felt particularly high. The Jets\u2019 successful regular season (second in the NHL\u2019s Western Conference) was clouded by dwindling attendance and concerning comments made by ownership about the team\u2019s future.Winnipeg is Canada\u2019s seventh-largest city. With a population of 758,000, it is the NHL\u2019s smallest market.The prairie hub proudly leans into its reputation as a large \u201Csmall town.\u201D The region boasts a rich history in the game \u2014 and a passionate fan base.But Winnipeg is often overlooked by players. The Jets appear with great frequency on the \u201Cno-trade\u201D lists of many contracts. High-profile players like Jacob Trouba, Evander Kane and PL Dubois have all forced their way out of town. In The Athletic\u2019s anonymous player poll, Winnipeg was declared the destination that players least liked to visit on the road, with 41.24 percent of the vote.That sentiment has a galvanizing effect on the fan base.\u201CThe perception is that people want us to fail,\u201D Burnett said, adding that the Jets faithful embrace the team\u2019s underdog position.Burnett wore a white Connor Hellebuyck jersey, the team\u2019s All-Star goalie who recently signed a seven-year deal to stay in Winnipeg and was named a finalist for the Vezina Trophy. Burnett\u2019s jersey could have been any member of the current Jets roster, aside from the team\u2019s most recent trade deadline acquisitions. He has a jersey for almost every player who has played multiple seasons in Winnipeg since the team\u2019s return more than a dozen years ago. His collection includes more than 60 jerseys from two generations of the Jets.AdvertisementI first met Burnett in 2011, when he was one of the 13,500 fans who signed up for season tickets in 17 minutes when the Atlanta Thrashers moved to the Canadian Prairies, becoming the second iteration of the Jets.He gave me a tour of the basement he\u2019d dedicated to the team that left the city for Arizona in 1996, which had become central to Burnett\u2019s life. Celia Burnett relinquished the basement to her husband, knowing he needed a place to address his anger and sadness at the Jets\u2019 move to Arizona. He turned it into a shrine that includes a miniature locker room, old jerseys, game programs and memorabilia that spoke to the love and agony that comes with being a fan. The final A from the Winnipeg Arena sign above the entrance of the now demolished building sat on a landing above the basement stairs. Gillian, the youngest of the Burnetts\u2019 four daughters, helped her father show off his prized Jets possessions.Gillian was 9 then. She\u2019s grown up sitting in the family\u2019s seats \u2014 section 312, row 5 \u2014 next to her father. She is now 22 and has a Winnipeg Jets tattoo on her forearm.\u201CI got it in honor of my dad, because that\u2019s what my dad is \u2014 the Winnipeg Jets,\u201D Gillian said. \u201CIt\u2019s part of him.\u201DShe sat next to her 78-year-old grandmother, Donna, on a concrete stoop in True North Square, as a DJ pumped music into the pregame festival. Donna, who wore a white and pink Jets zip-up hoodie, also never misses a game, not because of an obsession with an on-ice product but because of what the team means to her family.In the late 1970s, Donna bought season tickets to the original Jets franchise. For a single mother, the Jets became a way for her to connect with her rambunctious 8-year-old son. They drove more than a half-hour to each game and always went out to a restaurant they considered to be fancy. At the time, it was all doable on Donna\u2019s teacher salary.\u201CWe had a wonderful time,\u201D she said. \u201CI just loved it.\u201D Greg Burnett at the entrance of his Jets shrine. (Dan Robson / The Athletic)But that \u201Cwonderful time\u201D didn\u2019t last. In 1996, the original Jets franchise left for Arizona. When the ownership group True North announced in 2011 that it was purchasing the Atlanta Thrashers and moving the team to Winnipeg, Jets love was rekindled.The NHL\u2019s return kicked off a revival so fervent that the franchise nurtured a waiting list of several thousand people willing to purchase season tickets should a seat ever open up.AdvertisementThe Canada Life Centre is the smallest arena in the NHL, with a capacity of just more than 15,000. And for years the Jets boasted constant sellouts and one of the loudest fan bases in the league.But over the past couple of seasons, the Jets have had only a handful of sellouts.And then early this season, Greg Burnett started to feel that familiar pang of dread when he saw rows of empty seats inside the Jets home rink. It was a reminder of an underlying anxiety shared by many fans old enough to remember the first time the team left town.It was just the second home game of the 2023-24 season and only 11,226 fans showed up to watch the team play the L.A. Kings, the lowest attendance Burnett said he had ever seen at a Jets game.Things didn\u2019t get much better. Aside from the smoldering ashes of the Arizona Coyotes \u2014 the former Jets franchise playing out its final days at a 5,000-seat college rink \u2014 Winnipeg had the lowest attendance in the NHL this season, averaging 13,490 fans. By percentage of rink capacity, the Jets were third worst at 89.9 percent, ahead of only the Buffalo Sabres and San Jose Sharks. In Winnipeg, it was the continuation of a downward trend that started with the NHL\u2019s first full 82-game season after the Covid-19 pandemic.The Jets\u2019 season-ticket base shrunk by 27 percent in three years, falling to under 9,500 from close to 13,000.The team\u2019s mediocre results didn\u2019t help. The Jets missed the playoffs in 2022, then lost in the first round after barely squeaking into the postseason in 2023.Last spring, True North angered fans with a poorly conceived \u201CForever Winnipeg\u201D ticket drive.\u201CSo is Winnipeg an NHL city? You better believe it,\u201D narrator Kenny Omega, a Winnipeg-born wrestling star asks over sentimental visuals of Jets highlights and smiling fans, before the background music turns abruptly somber. \u201CBut it takes all of us.\u201DAdvertisementThe campaign was widely viewed as a not-so-veiled threat, recalling painful memories of the Jets\u2019 departure.In February, concern about the franchise\u2019s future was stoked by comments Mark Chipman, True North\u2019s chairman, made in an interview with The Athletic\u2019s Chris Johnston.\u201CI wouldn\u2019t be honest with you if I didn\u2019t say, \u2018We\u2019ve got to get back to 13,000,\u2019\u201D Chipman told Johnston. \u201CThis place we find ourselves in right now, it\u2019s not going to work over the long haul.\u201DIn the upper bowl, behind the visiting goal \u2014 section 312, row 5 \u2014 Greg, Gillian and Donna took their regular seats in the sea of white. The rink filled quickly, as it had through the final stretch of the regular season when the Jets sold out six of the team\u2019s last eight games. A late-season surge helped build excitement for the playoffs. The Jets carried an eight-game winning streak into the playoffs. They drew the Colorado Avalanche in the first round, a team they hadn\u2019t lost to all season and had recently stomped 7-0.Maybe the fans just needed a reason to believe?If that hope was fleeting with the Jets trailing 3-1 in the series, you wouldn\u2019t have noticed as the Jets took the ice for warmups in Game 5. The arena buzz rose to a crescendo.Just after warmups, Celia Burnett met her family at their seats, taking a quick break from her job working at the front gate of Canada Life Centre, ushering lively fans through the ticket line at Portage Avenue. The family was at the arena so much that a few years ago she decided it made sense that she get paid to be close by.\u201CIt\u2019s a constant,\u201D Celia said. \u201CIt\u2019s always about the Jets.\u201DThe arena thundered. The sold-out crowd twirled white towels and cheered at a relentless volume. Fans belted the words \u201CTrue North\u201D in unison when the Canadian national anthem lyrics were sung \u2014 a tradition that started with the team\u2019s inaugural season in 2011.AdvertisementOutside the Jets \u201Cwhiteout\u201D street party on Donald Street, next to the arena, another 5,000 fans packed as close to two massive projection screens. All wore white. Some reveled in more creative attire. Several wore full white bodysuits and white old-school goalie masks. One man wore a white beer-stained pinstripe suit. Another wore a Panda head. Jets fans packed the streets around the Canada Life Centre for Game 5. (David Lipnowski / Getty Images)Evan Chubaty wore a low-cut wedding dress he found at a thrift store, fastened by dirty shoelaces he borrowed from a pair of sneakers. He was 9 when the Jets arrived. He\u2019s not worried about them leaving. He thinks the fans would never actually let that happen.\u201CEveryone loves them,\u201D Chubaty said. \u201CIt\u2019s a huge part of Winnipeg. The city wouldn\u2019t be the same without them.\u201DBenny, the original Jets mascot, interrupted the conversation and got down on a furry blue knee in front of Chubaty.The Bloodworth family stood quietly amid the crowd of mostly twentysomethings, reflecting both the older and younger generation of fans. Shayne and Maureen Bloodworth brought their children out for the experience. Shayne was a \u201C1.0\u201D Jets fan.\u201CI\u2019m the old guy,\u201D he said, as a crush of well-imbibed fans weaved around the family.His 10-year-old twins \u2014 Max, who sat sleepily on his shoulders, and Jack who leaned against him \u2014 have grown up in the \u201C2.0\u201D era. They play minor hockey for the River East Royals and catch every Jets game they can stay awake for.\u201CIt\u2019s become a part of this city\u2019s culture, for sure,\u201D Shayne said. \u201CIt\u2019s brought a lot of people together.\u201DMoments later, the street erupted as Josh Morrissey scored for the Jets halfway through the second period, tying the game at two. But before the period was over, Colorado was ahead again.Greg Burnett admitted that his optimism was fading. The Jets were 20 minutes away from another first-round exit. Considering the empty seats of the regular season, the stakes felt especially high.\u201CI hope I\u2019m wrong,\u201D he said.So is Winnipeg an NHL city?Glen Hodgson, an Ottawa-based economist and expert in the economics of sports franchises, believes it is \u2014 but in a unique, inherently precarious way. Hodgson wrote a book on the business of sports franchises, developing a methodology with his co-author for evaluating whether a sports franchise would succeed or fail.AdvertisementAs a market, Winnipeg falls short in almost every key component. The population is too small, the per capita income is too low, and there are a dwindling number of corporations with a head office in Canada\u2019s windy city.\u201CBut then you get to the intangibles, like passion,\u201D Hodgson said. \u201CAnd Manitoba is off the chart.\u201DHodgson knows the psyche of the city\u2019s sports fans well. He grew up in Winnipeg and was a devoted follower of the CFL\u2019s Winnipeg Blue Bombers, the other franchise that holds a deeply rooted place in the region\u2019s culture and identity.For many, like Burnett, the NHL\u2019s return in 2011 was a miracle, faithfully prayed for.Nostalgia and pride alone were enough to sell the team to local fans. For more than a decade, True North was viewed as a savior.The franchise was able to operate in an \u201Cif you build it, they will come\u201D mode, Hodgson said.But after the pandemic, amid a wavering Canadian economy, high inflation, and growing dissatisfaction with rising prices, stringent policies and a perceived lack of appreciation from the organization, many fans decided to stay home. The magic faded. The season-ticket waiting list disappeared. And the franchise entered a new, critical era.Chipman later clarified his comments about the franchise\u2019s sustainability and season-ticket sales, saying he was referring to the team\u2019s ability to spend to the cap and ice a contender. Gary Bettman, the NHL commissioner, visited Winnipeg this winter and underscored his confidence in the city as an ideal hockey market \u2014 which is something he has previously said about several other cities that ended up losing NHL teams.But there is plenty of reason for Jets fans to be confident in the team\u2019s commitment to Winnipeg.The franchise\u2019s books are kept private, but Chipman has said it\u2019s never lost money since its inaugural NHL season. And there is plenty of cash underpinning it. David Thomson, one of True North\u2019s co-owners, is the richest person in Canada \u2014 and 21st richest in the world \u2014 with a net worth of $61.3 billion, according to Forbes.AdvertisementTrue North has also invested hundreds of millions into the city, revitalizing the area around Canada Life Centre with sparkling new office towers. Last year, the group announced a $500 million plan to redevelop a worn-down shopping center across the street from the arena, a healthcare and social services hub for the community.Still, Winnipeg remains a constrained market, Hodgson said. There are only so many businesses and people to commit to season tickets.Chipman has been candid about True North\u2019s missteps in taking the community of Jets fans for granted. At the same time, fans like Burnett say it\u2019s also on the community to re-up its commitment to the team. He\u2019s reached out to friends who\u2019ve let their season tickets lapse in recent years, urging them to come back.The team\u2019s future likely depends on that rekindled relationship.\u201CIf you\u2019re asking the fundamental question, is the market really big enough to sustain over time, it really depends on engaging the passion,\u201D Hodgson said.\u201CIf any city is going to make it with those limitations, it will be Winnipeg.\u201D The Jets didn\u2019t have any trouble filling the stands for Game 5 of their first-round series against the Avalanche. (David Lipnowski / Getty Images)As the Colorado Avalanche pulled away from the Jets, those passionate fans started to head for the exits.\u0026nbsp;Before the final horn sounded on a 6-3 Avalanche win, large sections of the stands sat empty. Celia watched people stream through the doors onto Portage Avenue.Gillian joined her friends who\u2019d watched from the street party, which emptied off Donald Street within minutes. Hundreds of crushed silver cans sparkled beneath the street lights.In section 312, Greg sat next to his mother, watching the teams shake hands, trying to process another lost opportunity. As the players left the ice, Greg helped Donna from her seat and carefully guided her down the steep stadium stairs.He paused for a moment in the atrium, trying to describe the dejection he knew would linger u\u200B\u200Bntil the Jets begin again. A deep playoff run would certainly have stoked deeper interest in the team across the city. But this first-round exit felt perilously familiar.Advertisement\u201CYou know, as a Winnipeger,\u201D Greg said, \u201Cit feels like we can\u2019t have nice things.\u201DDonna smiled softly. Her son extended his arm and she took it. They walked away together, disappearing among the fans left and leaving.(Illustration: Eamonn Dalton / The Athletic. Photos: David Lipnowski / Getty Images; Jonathan Kozub / NHLI via Getty Images) Get all-access to exclusive stories.Subscribe to The Athletic for in-depth coverage of your favorite players, teams, leagues and clubs. This Football Coach Put an End to That.","Url":"https://theathletic.com/5475796/2024/05/08/oregon-football-coach-dan-lanning/","Text":"Think Dan Lanning will leave Oregon? Check the ink - The AthleticNCAAFTeamsScores \u0026amp; ScheduleStandingsPodcastsUntil Saturday newsletterRecruitingOddsPicksTransfer Portal TrackerThink Dan Lanning will leave Oregon? Check the ink Christopher KamraniMay 8, 2024EUGENE, Ore. \u2014 Somewhere in those 6.5 hours of perpetual pain, Dan Lanning\u2019s phone lit up. But he didn\u2019t see it. He was wincing. He was breathing deeply. Alec Turner, the artist tasked with completing the massive tattoo on the left side of Lanning\u2019s chest, saw the name on the screen, and his eyes bulged.AdvertisementThe incoming call? Phil Knight.So Turner removed the needle piercing the ribs of Oregon\u2019s gregarious football coach and deadpanned: \u201CHey, man, you should probably answer this.\u201DWhen Phil Knight calls, you stop what you\u2019re doing. Lanning sat on the table, swiped his phone screen and took a respite to talk to the founder of Nike and Oregon\u2019s most famed alumnus and donor. Lanning told Knight where he was and what he was cramming into one session.The permanent portrait of Lanning\u2019s wife, Sauphia, is sprinkled with various homages to their journey through life \u2014and football \u2014 together. \u0026nbsp; View this post on Instagram \u0026nbsp; A post shared by Alec Turner (@alecturnertattoos) Before Turner dipped the needle in ink on Jan. 4, 2023, he offered Lanning numbing cream. Lanning declined but now admits that, as the hours dragged on, he regretted that decision. He thought to himself: I\u2019m a football coach, right? I should be able to handle this.\u201CI just didn\u2019t have a big window of time,\u201D Lanning says. \u201CPain is weakness leaving the body. Let\u2019s go. Knock it out.\u201DHe had just finished his first year as head football coach at Oregon, where the Ducks won 10 games, were in the College Football Playoff conversation most of the season and had a top-10 recruiting ranking for the 2023 class. He was already hooked on life in Eugene.These were the first steps in Lanning\u2019s project to not only build Oregon into a winner his way, but to sustain it for years to come. His second season with the Ducks in 2023 was another step forward, showcased by a record-setting offense that wowed even a fan base accustomed to them.But nearly a year to the date he had his map charted in ink, the ultimate test of allegiance arose.On Jan. 10, 2024, Alabama\u2019s Nick Saban announced his retirement, rocking the college football universe. Lists of candidates to replace the seven-time national championship-winning head coach were formulated by the sport\u2019s insiders almost immediately. Most put Lanning at the epicenter of the speculation cycle.AdvertisementThe Lanning-to-Alabama conjecture lasted not even 24 hours, despite false reports that he was in Tuscaloosa interviewing to replace the legend for whom he\u2019d once worked. It ended with a close-up of Lanning, puffing smoke from a cigar, announcing that he was \u2014 as he says again and again \u2014 \u201C10 toes down\u201D in Eugene.Ask Lanning if he turned down Alabama, and he flashes a grin. \u201CWhen you\u2019re in a situation where your answer is already going to be no, people don\u2019t ask you those questions.\u201DAt Oregon, Lanning enjoys a fully guaranteed deal that pays more than $7 million a year through the 2029 season and requires a $20 million buyout to leave early, in addition to the perks of running a program with the support of Nike\u2019s deep pockets. But conventional wisdom posits that most coaches linked to the highest profile and most illustrious job in the sport would at least open up a lane for communication.Lanning, turns out, isn\u2019t all that conventional.The digital clock inside Lanning\u2019s office runs vertically on the wall to the right of his vast desk. The Ducks-green seconds tick away alongside the minutes and hours to tell Lanning how much time he has. On this visit, he would turn 38 the next day, but Lanning would rather talk about anything else.\u201CTwenty-one is the last time I celebrated a birthday,\u201D he says.So what about how, at 19, on a waiter\u2019s salary at Outback Steakhouse, he purchased a house on Elizabeth Street in Liberty, Mo., while balancing life as a Division II linebacker at William Jewell College? He had four teammates move in who helped pay the mortgage. It\u2019s been nearly 20 years since they huddled together for Nintendo 64 tournaments. If a roommate was short one month, Lanning would cover for them. But he wouldn\u2019t forget about it.Leaning forward in a chair, Lanning says, \u201CRealizing early you can create your own success with hard work is something that stuck out with me.\u201DAdvertisementTrent Figg, head coach at Division III Calvin University in Grand Rapids, Mich., is one of Lanning\u2019s former teammates and roommates. Figg says Lanning hasn\u2019t changed since he\u2019s ascended college football\u2019s coaching ladder. Figg\u2019s scouting report of his friend Dan Lanning (not head football coach Dan Lanning) is succinct: He\u2019s a social butterfly and the life of the party at all times. He loves action movies. He likes to smoke a cigar. He likes to cook steak on his own stovetop. He still wears white Nike dress socks to work every day. \u201CThat,\u201D Lanning says, \u201Cis mostly true.\u201DLanning\u2019s former roommates and former employers offer up a common theme: He carries with him a unique devotion to people who believe in him.\u201CHe\u2019s the most loyal person I\u2019ve ever been around,\u201D says Figg. \u201CLike, if you talk about why he stayed in Eugene instead of going to Alabama, he sees the value in how people have invested in him, and he fully believes in himself. He\u2019s a very confident person. And he totally believes in what he has at Oregon.\u201DIt\u2019s been over a decade since Lanning left his post as recruiting coordinator at Sam Houston State in Huntsville, Texas. Longtime head coach K.C. Keeler remembers when Lanning approached him and said he got a call from Saban to join Alabama\u2019s staff as a graduate assistant for the 2015 season. Lanning\u2019s body language was telling, Keeler says; he wasn\u2019t grinning. He felt like he was going to let Keeler down.Keeler told Lanning he had to go, because that\u2019s where he\u2019d meet someone who would eventually notice him as a future head coach.\u201CIt doesn\u2019t take you long to figure out Dan Lanning\u2019s style,\u201D Keeler says. \u201CI remember telling my wife back then, \u2018I\u2019m going to have this guy for a year.\u2019 This guy was always on a different path.\u201DThat path is forever detailed on his ribs, shown through Sauphia\u2019s portrait.The Oregon symbol on her neck features a yellow ribbon in the center, commemorating her battle with an aggressive type of bone cancer in 2016. Their three sons, Caden, Kniles and Titan, are there. There\u2019s the state of Texas outline for Sam Houston State, the Sun Devils pitchfork from Lanning\u2019s time as a graduate assistant at Arizona State, the Pitt emblem for his year with the Panthers and Alabama\u2019s signature \u201CA.\u201D There\u2019s a boomerang honoring Outback Steakhouse, where Dan and Sauphia met as co-workers. The \u201C816\u201D is the area code of Lanning\u2019s hometown in Missouri, and 33-18 is the score of Georgia\u2019s win over Alabama in the national championship after the 2021 season when he was the Bulldogs defensive coordinator.Advertisement\u201CIt definitely hurt,\u201D Lanning says.The tribute to his life\u2019s work isn\u2019t meant as an ode to himself. It\u2019s to his wife, his kids, his faith, his journey, the night shifts at Outback when he was courting Sauphia by paying for her 18th birthday dinner. It\u2019s also a reminder to Lanning that the work is just starting.\u201CThe seat I sit in now, I remember what it was like when I wasn\u2019t sitting in it,\u201D Lanning says. \u201CLoyalty to me is giving the best you got every day, 10 toes down on the job that you\u2019re responsible for and owning that and realizing success will come from that. I get to live my dream. I get to do exactly what I signed up for and what I\u2019d hoped.\u201DExisting in one\u2019s dream doesn\u2019t mean it\u2019s without its constant demands. The home office where he does video calls lately doesn\u2019t have an impressive array of trophies and photos in the background; the office is his closet. It\u2019s where he can tap in when needed to talk to players, parents or recruits. And when that\u2019s done, it\u2019s done, and he\u2019s out on the couch informing his three boys the night\u2019s movie is \u201CField of Dreams\u201D or \u201CBack to the Future.\u201D\u201CIn a lot of ways in our jobs now, you\u2019re a doctor on-call,\u201D he says. \u201CSomething can happen at any moment and it requires your attention. What I think I\u2019m getting better at is making sure I take advantage of those moments when it does arise. I\u2019ve been poor at that. I\u2019ve gone through basketball seasons where I got to see my son play once. That\u2019s not something I\u2019m proud of. I want to get better at it.\u201DHe may sound like how a football coach is supposed to sound when he\u2019s dissecting depth charts in media scrums, but Lanning is not a caricature of a football coach. It\u2019s helped, he says, that the stops that brought him to Oregon have meant working for Saban, Georgia\u2019s Kirby Smart, Florida State\u2019s Mike Norvell and others.\u201CGreat head coaches have to be themselves,\u201D Lanning says. \u201CIf they try and be something else, or if you do what you think everybody else is doing, then you catch yourself in a trap.\u201DAdvertisementOne avoids such traps by staying a step ahead. And Lanning, his friends and colleagues say, always has been. Since he was a 26-year-old on-campus recruiting coordinator at Arizona State, he possessed a preternatural ability to recruit.And apparently he doesn\u2019t miss when a window into his world swings open. Before Oregon\u2019s 42-6 trouncing of Colorado last September, Lanning allowed ABC cameras into the Ducks\u2019 locker room to capture a speech that went viral. Speaking of Deion Sanders\u2019 Buffaloes becoming the topic du jour of the sports world, Lanning told his team, \u201CThey\u2019re fighting for clicks, we\u2019re fighting for wins.\u201DIt was a flashpoint in the 24-hour news cycle. The payoff was a glimpse for recruits to see that what you see with Lanning is what you get. Oregon coach Dan Lanning catches raindrops on his tongue before the Ducks\u2019 game against Cal on Nov. 4, 2023. (Ali Gradischer / Getty Images)For much of the past decade, Oregon fans felt slighted, because they invested in two head coaches who vowed that Eugene was the place for them, that they\u2019d guide the Ducks to title contention, only to leave for other jobs. Willie Taggart spent one year as head coach in 2017 before leaving for Florida State. His replacement, Mario Cristobal, coached four years at Oregon and ultimately left to coach his alma mater, Miami.So imagine the level of paranoia when college football pundits listed Lanning as their guy to replace Saban. Lanning quashed it with the minute-long video. \u201CWhen good things happen, speculation occurs \u2014 and there\u2019s been a lot of good things that happened to us at Oregon,\u201D Lanning says.Before it saw the light of day on social media, on the night of Jan. 10, Lanning was on the phone with the mother of a recruit who was afraid that their decision to choose Oregon would be fleeting. She\u2019d read the headlines connecting him with the Alabama job.\u201CI said, \u2018If I made an announcement for you, would that make it clear exactly what we\u2019re going to do?\u2019\u201D Lanning recalls. \u201CThe mom said that, \u2018Yeah, that makes it really clear.\u2019 And then I told her, \u2018Hopefully at some point they\u2019ll stop asking the question.\u2019\u201DAdvertisementNew Oregon quarterback Dillon Gabriel says even though he\u2019s been on campus for only four months, Lanning\u2019s confidence in his program is infectious.\u201CHow cool is that? That\u2019s who I committed to,\u201D Gabriel says. \u201CThat coach is the guy everyone wants for the right reasons. He\u2019s great at connecting with people, he listens, he understands, he can translate that into action from a guy who\u2019s been in it for a long time. Everything he\u2019s said has come to fruition. He just keeps it real, and I think you can appreciate that. He just does the easy things at an elite level. He\u2019s mastered it. That\u2019s exactly why people want him.\u201DThe Ducks are 22-5 in two years under Lanning and have cultivated one of the sport\u2019s most explosive offenses with offensive coordinator Willie Stein calling the plays. With Heisman Trophy finalist Bo Nix at the helm last year, the Ducks ranked No. 2 in the country in total offense. Oregon\u2019s defense finished top 25 in overall team defense, too. But the undoing of the team\u2019s College Football Playoff aspirations were two agonizingly close losses to rival Washington.The Ducks now prepare for a new era as they enter the Big Ten alongside the Huskies, USC and UCLA. Asked why he thinks this year\u2019s Ducks have a shot at contending in the expanded 12-team playoff, Lanning says they\u2019ve always been aggressive in looking to increase the talent on their roster, through recruiting high school players (the Ducks ranked No. 3 in the 247Sports recruiting team composite rankings in 2024) and in the NCAA transfer portal.During the winter portal window, they added Gabriel (Oklahoma), cornerbacks Jabbar Muhammad (Washington) and Kam Alexander (UTSA), wide receiver Evan Stewart (Texas A\u0026amp;M) and former five-star recruit and UCLA QB Dante Moore. In the last week, the Ducks have further bolstered their defense with safety Peyton Woodyard (Alabama) and defensive lineman Derrick Harmon (Michigan State). Lanning staying put and believing he\u2019s in Eugene for the long term has set up Oregon for both the present and the future.\u201CDan likes to prove people wrong,\u201D Figg says. \u201CDan knows he can win a national championship at Oregon, and he wants to show the world he can do it.\u201DOregon is no longer an upstart. The Ducks made a national championship appearance, though it was nearly a decade ago in 2015. Lanning believes the program can win it all in this quaint remote town thousands of miles away from where the Southeastern Conference has reigned supreme the past two decades.Advertisement\u201CI love being part of a program that\u2019s proactive,\u201D Lanning says. \u201CThey\u2019ve always wanted a great product. This is a place where you can create that.\u201DLanning talks about making the jump from good to great. The Ducks being agonizingly close in big games has to change in the Big Ten era. Ohio State visits Oct. 12, and three weeks later, the Ducks go to The Big House to face reigning national champion Michigan on Nov. 2.With his ribs aflame with pain after being tattooed, Lanning posed for Turner so he could share the work done in one sitting on Instagram. Turner was born and raised in Eugene. For years, he has tattooed Oregon players and the \u201CO\u201D symbol on fans. Never could he have imagined Chip Kelly or Mike Bellotti walking into his shop. But in talking to Lanning, Turner says he felt like the head coach is sold on the life and pace of his hometown.Before Lanning walked out the doors, he told Turner something the artist now fully believes.\u201CHe told me he wanted to retire here,\u201D Turner says.(Illustration: Eamonn Dalton / The Athletic; photos: Tom Hauck / Getty Images) Get all-access to exclusive stories.Subscribe to The Athletic for in-depth coverage of your favorite players, teams, leagues and clubs. Instead, he wants to take the Ducks to places they\u2019ve never been.","PublishDate":"2024-05-08T15:14:45","IsHeadline":true,"IsPaywall":false,"Summary":"Dan Lanning is leaving Oregon after 13 seasons as head coach. He made the decision due to a combination of factors including his age and health concerns, along with wanting more opportunities for personal growth outside football.\n\nLaning has had an impactful impact on Ducks fans during their time in Eugene. The team reached new heights under him both offensively and defensively while consistently competing at high levels nationally. \n\n\nHe leaves behind a legacy that includes championship appearances, strong recruiting efforts, and a commitment to the university\u0027s values of loyalty, hard work, and faith.","ImageURL":"https://cdn.theathletic.com/app/uploads/2024/05/07235302/0424_DanLanning-2-scaled.jpg","PublisherID":3,"Business":true,"CompaniesMentioned":"FUTR.L (Future),","HasJakeFlag":false},{"Title":"Peace starts with Palestine\u2019s UN membership","Url":"https://www.aljazeera.com/opinions/2024/5/8/peace-starts-with-palestines-un-membership?traffic_source=rss","Text":"Peace starts with Palestine\u2019s UN membership | United Nations | Al Jazeera Skip linksSkip to Contentplay Live Show navigation menuNavigation menuNewsShow more news sectionsMiddle EastAfricaAsiaUS \u0026amp; CanadaLatin AmericaEuropeAsia PacificIsrael War on GazaFeaturesOpinionVideoMoreShow more sectionsEconomyUkraine warCoronavirusClimate CrisisInvestigationsInteractivesIn PicturesScience \u0026amp; TechnologySportPodcastsplay Live Click here to searchsearchOPINIONOPINION, Opinions|United NationsPeace starts with Palestine\u2019s UN membershipOn May 10, all member states should vote to admit the State of Palestine as the 194th member of the United Nations.By Jeffrey Sachs\u0026nbsp;and\u0026nbsp;Sybil FaresPublished On 8 May 20248 May 2024[AP Photo/Ted Shaffrey, File]On May 10, the United Nations\u2019 193 member states can end the Gaza war and the longstanding suffering of the Palestinian people by voting to admit Palestine as the 194th UN member state. The Arab world has repeatedly declared its readiness to establish relations with Israel within the context of the two-state solution. This goes back to the 2002 Arab Peace Initiative and has been reiterated in the 2023 Arab-Islamic Extraordinary Summit. On May 16, leaders of the region will gather for the 33rd Arab League Summit, where yet another plea for peace and stability will likely be made.Keep reading list of 4 itemslist 1 of 4The everyday items you never knew contained plasticlist 2 of 4UN chief urges Israel and Hamas to reach ceasefire deal in Gazalist 3 of 4Turkey seeks to join South Africa\u2019s genocide case against Israel at ICJlist 4 of 4ICJ rejects Nicaragua\u2019s request to halt German arms sales to Israelend of list The way to end the war and normalise relations in the Middle East is clear. Admit the State of Palestine to the UN, on the 1967 borders, with its capital in East Jerusalem and with control over the Muslim holy sites. Then, diplomatic relations will be established and mutual security of both Israel and Palestine will be assured. The vast majority of the world certainly agrees on the two-state solution as it is enshrined in international law and UN resolutions. Today, 142 of the 193 countries officially recognise the State of Palestine, but the United States has so far blocked Palestine\u2019s membership to the UN, where statehood really counts. Israel continues to harbour its dream \u2013 and the world\u2019s nightmare \u2013 of continued apartheid rule. Barbados, Jamaica, and Trinidad and Tobago have very recently established diplomatic relations with the State of Palestine, and the General Assembly is poised to vote an overwhelming endorsement of Palestine\u2019s membership. The unity of the global community for Palestine\u2019s political self-determination is also reflected on college campuses across the US, United Kingdom and the rest of the world. Students know the torment of apartheid and plausible genocide when they see it; and are actively demanding an end to the torment. According to Article 4 of the UN Charter, admission is effected by a decision of the General Assembly following a recommendation of the Security Council. On April 18, the Security Council\u2019s vote on Palestinian membership was vetoed by the US, but with 12 out of the 15 council members voting in favour. The UK abstained, as if it\u2019s not already made enough of a mess in the region. Because of the US veto, the General Assembly will take up the issue during an Emergency Special Session on May 10. This vote will show an overwhelming support of Palestine\u2019s membership. It will then be taken up again by the Security Council. Our point is to put UN membership upfront. Peace will never be achieved at the end of another \u201Cpeace process,\u201D as with the failed Oslo process, nor by the whims of imperial powers who have perpetually devastated the region. Israel\u2019s leaders today are dead set against the two-state solution and the US and UK have been dead set in defence of Israel\u2019s rejection of it. The US and UK have repeatedly destroyed the two-state solution by always being for it, but never just now. They have favoured endless negotiations while Israel pursues its apartheid system, a war constituting a plausible case of genocide, and illegal settlements as \u201Cfacts on the ground\u201D. In welcoming Palestine as a UN member state, the UN would also take crucial steps to ensure the security of both Israel and Palestine. Peace would be enforced by international law, and the backing of the UN Security Council, the Arab States, and indeed the world community. This moment has been more than a century in coming. In 1917, Britain declared a province of the Ottoman Empire, which did not belong to it, as the Jewish homeland. The next 30 years were wracked by violence leading to the Nakba and then to repeated wars. After the 1967 war, when Israel conquered the remaining Palestinian lands, it administered an apartheid state. Israeli society became increasingly hardened to its rule, with extremist Israelis and Palestinians on each side of the bitter divide that only widens. The US and UK have been brazenly and cynically dishonest brokers. The politics in both countries has long been Zionist to the core, meaning that both countries almost always side with Israel regardless of justice and law. We have arrived at a truly historic moment to end decades of violence. No more peace processes to be undermined by political manipulations. Peace can come through the immediate implementation of the two-state solution, with the admission of Palestine to the UN as the starting point, not the end. Diplomatic recognition should build in and invite further crucial steps for mutual security. It is time, on May 10, for all UN member states to uphold international law and vote for justice and peace. EducationIn PicturesNewsbeatBBC VerifyDisabilityHealthBehind-scenes NHS problems leave new doctors without jobsPublished3 days agoShareclose panelShare pageCopy linkAbout sharingRelated TopicsCoronavirus Image source, EmmaImage caption, Emma is graduating from medical school this yearBy Nick TriggleHealth correspondentThe NHS needs more doctors, and this year saw a record number of applications from medical students to start junior doctor training. But problems behind the scenes have meant many have not yet been found jobs. What has gone wrong?When the email of congratulations arrived in her inbox last month, Emma could not have been any more excited. Inside was meant to be the details of her first job as a junior doctor.On the brink of graduation from Warwick Medical School, the 29-year-old was due to find out about where she would working for the next two years.But despite the email being titled congratulations, next to each of her placements for her two-year foundation course, the first rung on the doctor training ladder, was the abbreviation TBC.Image caption, Emma\u0026#x27;s email did not confirm where she would be workingShe had been given what is called a placeholder job. \u0026quot;I\u0026#x27;ve been told I will have a job, but that they don\u0026#x27;t know where yet and it could take until three weeks before I am due to start in August for me to find out. All I know is it will be somewhere in the West Midlands South region.\u0026quot;It is incredibly unsettling. It makes you feel unvalued and an inconvenience. The NHS is short of doctors and yet they cannot find me a job.\u0026quot;I am renting at the moment, but depending on where I am placed I may have to give notice to my landlord and move.\u0026quot;Emma was one of more than 1,000 medical students in this position when the emails initially went out. That was nearly one in nine of those who have applied to start junior doctor training this summer.Since then the numbers have dropped to 800 as NHS trusts have created new roles and some students have already decided not to take up their place.Part of the problem is that there has been an increase in medical students this summer to start junior doctor training, with just over 9,700 accepted by the UK Foundation Programme, up from 8,655 in 2023.Some of these will have come from abroad, and under immigration rules the NHS cannot prioritise UK-trained students.The increase is welcome given the need to train more doctors, with the government in England aiming to double the number of medical student places by 2031.But it has meant NHS trusts have struggled to keep up and ensure they have enough training posts for new graduates. \u0026#x27;A lottery\u0026#x27;The British Medical Association has this week written to the health secretary to warn it is \u0026quot;exceedingly concerned\u0026quot; about the placeholder situation, after being inundated with complaints from worried medical students.Its letter says many are reporting they may only be told where they will be three weeks before their August start date, when work schedules are meant to be confirmed at least eight weeks in advance.All they know is what part of the UK they are going to be working in after being allocated to one of 18 foundation school areas in March. Some cover very large areas. There is one each for Wales, Scotland and Northern Ireland, while in England, one covers the whole of Yorkshire and Humber. Medical students have also had to cope with a change in the way their regions are allocated. As part of the process, they have to list each foundation school in order of preference.Previously people were allocated according to merit - with each student ranked according to how they had performed during their studies and in an application test.But this year that has changed and has been done randomly. The logic behind it was that the previous system was stressful for students and was particularly unfair on those from deprived backgrounds and ethnic minorities. They tended to perform less well, and therefore were more likely to be posted to regions they did not favour, according to the UK Foundation Programme.However, overall it has resulted in more students not ending up with one of their top five choices - more than 730 compared to just over 430 last year.Image source, Getty ImagesBMA medical students committee deputy chairman Rob Tucker says while students understood the logic behind changing the system, he feels \u0026quot;something has gone wrong\u0026quot; given what has happened. \u0026quot;Students feel like they are in a lottery. It all depends what number the computer algorithm spits out.\u0026quot;And he is worried it will lead to more people dropping out and not progressing on to the next stage of training.\u0026quot;Having more students with their bottom choices, and so many with placeholder jobs, increases the chances of more medical students walking away.\u0026quot;It\u0026#x27;s very hard if you end up in a part of the country you don\u0026#x27;t want to work [in] and then if you don\u0026#x27;t know where you are going to work in that particular region until as little as a few weeks before you start, that\u0026#x27;s not fair.\u0026quot;It costs a lot of money to train a doctor. It\u0026#x27;s good value if they work for the NHS for 30 or 40 years, but not if you lose them straight away.\u0026quot;\u0026#x27;Bottlenecks\u0026#x27;There is sympathy for their plight among those running the system.Speaking at the Royal College of Physicians annual conference last month, North London Foundation School deputy director Dr Celia Bielawski said the deaneries were working hard with NHS trusts to create the new junior doctor posts needed.\u0026quot;We have an increasing number of international medical graduates applying for foundation training every year, and the government is very keen that we should take these doctors as we need to train up additional doctors to go up through the ranks. \u0026quot;At the moment we don\u0026#x27;t have places for all of them, but we are all actively working, creating additional posts and I\u0026#x27;m confident that they will all be placed. \u0026quot;We have to get trusts to agree to take them, that\u0026#x27;s one of the fundamental issues and bottlenecks with all of this. But we\u0026#x27;ll get there, I am sure.\u0026quot; Prof Sheona Macleod, director of education and training at NHS England, is confident the situation will be resolved too, saying: \u0026quot;We will get there because we\u0026#x27;ve committed to finding them a post.\u0026quot;But she also pointed out that under the previous system, medical students could still find themselves without a job initially as some would be placed on a national reserve list after the first round of job offers.\u0026quot;We have made sure people know where they are going, as in what region, which is different to the past.\u0026quot; But she added: \u0026quot;The numbers have meant that the anxiety for the students looking at finding places hasn\u0026#x27;t gone away and we\u0026#x27;re very aware of it.\u0026quot;Additional reporting by Catherine Snowdon.Related TopicsMedicineNHSBritish Medical Association (BMA)Coronavirus Top StoriesTory MP Natalie Elphicke defects to LabourPublished3 hours agoThe inside story of Tory MP\u0026#x27;s defection to LabourPublished4 hours agoHarry and King at events two miles apart but do not meetPublished1 hour agoFeaturesCould Ofcom ban social media for under-18s?The inside story of Tory MP\u0026#x27;s defection to LabourNatalie Elphicke: who is the new Labour MP?Going to the extreme: Inside Germany\u2019s far rightOceans suffer from record-breaking year of heatJames Landale: US bomb delay is biggest warning yet for IsraelWho will compete in the Eurovision final?Japanese role-playing game joins Download FestivalTeen drama turns tables on \u0026#x27;toxic parents\u0026#x27;Elsewhere on the BBCPowerful, premium US dramaThe true story of the dealers, doctors and the billion dollar drug that fuelled America\u0026#x27;s deadly opioid addiction.AttributioniPlayerWhen do you become an adult?Lecturer Laura Tisdall explains the shifting milestones of adulthoodAttributionSoundsThe Kinsellas are back and thrivingWatch the second series of the hit crime drama exclusively on BBC iPlayerAttributioniPlayerThe surprising history of the forkFrom its controversial beginnings in Italy to a battle against bad manners in FranceAttributionSoundsMost Read1Revenge porn video like \u0026#x27;house fire\u0026#x27;, star tells MPs2US indie music giant Steve Albini dies at 613Harry and King at London events but not meeting4Woman has cyclist manslaughter conviction quashed5Tory MP Natalie Elphicke defects to Labour6Agency charging NHS nearly \u00A32,000 for nurse shift7Dine and dash couple failed to pay \u00A31,000 in bills8Forbes \u0026#x27;honoured\u0026#x27; Read about our approach to external linking.","RSSSummary":"The NHS needs more doctors so why have some medical students been left in limbo waiting for a job?","PublishDate":"2024-05-05T01:32:46","IsHeadline":true,"IsPaywall":false,"Summary":"The NHS faces a critical challenge in finding sufficient doctors, with many new medical students facing delays and uncertainty regarding their placements as junior doctor trainees due to increased applications outpacing available training posts. This surge has been partly attributed to an influx of international graduates seeking foundation positions alongside the government\u0027s drive for more healthcare professionals through initiatives like expanding student numbers by 2031.\n\nThe lack of clarity in job allocation and frequent changes have caused significant anxiety among students, leading some to question their future prospects within NHS training programs. The situation highlights concerns about fairness amidst a competitive recruitment process that prioritizes merit-based placements over regional considerations or individual preferences. This mismatch between the algorithm\u0027s logic and student needs threatens retention rates and creates uncertainty for aspiring doctors entering this crucial phase of medical education.\n\nThe BBC investigation underscores the need to address bottlenecks in healthcare staffing, ensuring efficient allocation processes and fair access to training opportunities without compromising on quality standards within NHS institutions","ImageURL":"https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/news/1024/branded_news/B92D/production/_101650474_gettyimages-526223747.jpg","PublisherID":2,"Business":true,"CompaniesMentioned":"","HasJakeFlag":false},{"Title":"Election poll tracker: How do the parties compare?","Url":"https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-politics-68079726","Text":"General election 2024 poll tracker: How do the parties compare? - BBC NewsBBC HomepageSkip to contentAccessibility HelpYour accountNotificationsHomeNewsSportWeatheriPlayerSoundsBitesizeMore menuMore menuSearch BBCHomeNewsSportWeatheriPlayerSoundsBitesizeCBBCCBeebiesFoodClose menuBBC NewsMenuHomeIsrael-Gaza warCost of LivingWar in UkraineIndia ElectionClimateUKWorldBusinessPoliticsMoreCultureTechScienceHealthFamily \u0026amp; EducationIn PicturesNewsbeatBBC VerifyDisabilityPoliticsParliamentsBrexitGeneral election 2024 poll tracker: How do the parties compare?Published12 hours agoShareclose panelShare pageCopy linkAbout sharingUse our interactive poll tracker to check the latest trends measuring how people say they intend to vote. Sample size: 1508, funded by Independent 8 - 10 Jan 20 BMG 1,508Independent 44 29 11 5 4 3 0 Scroll vertically or horizontally to see more polling data Scroll table to see more polling data Show more * \u0026#x3D; Polling company conducted interviews either partly or entirely by telephone. All other polls were online. What is a poll tracker?Each dot in the chart shows one poll result for a party. We summarise all that information with an average line that makes it easier to understand the trend.Which polls do we use?To get an appropriate range of polls for our averages, we use those conducted by members of the British Polling Council.Its members agree to the same rules on transparency, but the council has said membership should not be seen as a guarantee of quality.The polls we include have come from BMG, Deltapoll, Find Out Now, focaldata, Ipsos, JL Partners, More in Common, Opinium, Panelbase, People Polling, Redfield and Wilton Strategies, Survation, Techne, Verian (formerly Kantar Public), WeThink (formerly Omnisis), Whitestone Insight and YouGov.We only include the headline percentages on voting intention, which pollsters calculate by excluding those people who answered \u0026quot;don\u0026#x27;t know\u0026quot; or \u0026quot;won\u0026#x27;t vote\u0026quot;.Most of the polls included cover Great Britain, although some do poll the whole of the UK. People surveyed do not get the option to choose parties which only stand in Northern Ireland.We include data that is in the public domain. Some polling companies will not publish all data for all parties at the same time.Who pays for polls?Where polling companies have stated in their data tables who their client is, we have included this in our table. It is common for polling companies to do their work for news organisations, television programmes and campaign groups. What is the margin of error?The true position for the Conservatives and Labour might be within five percentage points of our average.Nine out of 10 polls just before election day have been within that range of the eventual national vote shares in the 2010 to 2019 general elections.The gap has been smaller for other parties which campaign throughout Great Britain and smaller still for the SNP and Plaid Cymru.How do we average the polls?Our estimate of a party\u0026#x27;s support is a rolling average of polls.A party\u0026#x27;s share on any given day is the average of their results from polls taken over the previous fortnight. We only take the most recent poll from each company for that day\u0026#x27;s averages.Why do polling companies have different results?All opinion polls will differ a bit because they are interviewing different people. There are also other things that can lead to differences between polling companies. For example:Different companies find the people who take part in their polls in different waysThe precise wording of the question varies between pollsters, and some pollsters ask more than one question to reach their voting intention figuresPollsters apply \u0026quot;weights\u0026quot; to their data to try to make their results reflect the make-up of the voting population. So if a particular poll has a smaller proportion of female respondents than there are in the wider population, their responses will be given extra weight in the final results. But different companies take different factors into accountThe companies have different ways of treating people who initially say they do not know how they will vote, or are not certain if they will vote.What do pollsters ask?For voting intention, polling companies typically ask interviewees a question along the lines of: \u0026quot;If a general election were held tomorrow, which party would you vote for?\u0026quot;Some polling companies have not given their interviewees the choice of some parties, including them within the \u0026quot;other\u0026quot; category.For example, Reform UK, formerly the Brexit Party until 2021, has only been included as an option in every poll featured in our tracker since autumn 2022, while support for Plaid Cymru is included among \u0026quot;other\u0026quot; parties in polls released by Techne.Produced by Grace Richardson, Scott Jarvis, Becky Rush, Allison Shultes, Libby Rogers, Daniel Wainwright, Aidan McNamee, Jana Tauschinski, Debie Loizou, Preeti Vaghela, Robert Cuffe, John Walton.Related TopicsConservative PartyScottish GreensPlaid CymruPalace of WestminsterUK ParliamentReform UKGreen Party (England and Wales)Labour PartyLiberal DemocratsBrexit PartySNP (Scottish National Party)BBC News ServicesOn your mobileOn smart speakersGet news alertsContact BBC NewsBest of the BBCPowerful vocals, spectacle and drama!AttributionBBC iPlayerProvocative satire with Michael SpicerAttributionBBC SoundsTony Mammoth is a man out of timeAttributionBBC iPlayerFrom the pitch to the pod...AttributionBBC SoundsHomeNewsSportWeatheriPlayerSoundsCBBCCBeebiesFoodBitesizeArtsTasterLocalThreeTerms of UseAbout the BBCPrivacy PolicyCookiesAccessibility HelpParental GuidanceContact the BBCMake an editorial complaintGet Personalised NewslettersWhy you can trust the BBC\u00A9 2024 BBC.
