Contact support with reference ID provided if needed concerning this matter.","ImageURL":"?","PublisherID":27,"Business":true,"CompaniesMentioned":"","Author":"UNKNOWN AUTHOR","HasJakeFlag":false},{"Title":"Mexico City is sinking, running out of water: How can it be saved?","Url":"https://www.aljazeera.com/features/2024/5/11/mexico-city-is-sinking-running-out-of-water-how-can-it-be-saved?traffic_source=rss","Text":"Mexico City, Mexico \u2013 Walking through Mexico City\u2019s historic Zocalo district, Dario Solano-Rojas points to signs of a subterranean catastrophe that is under way.\r\n\r\nThe roads are uneven in the city\u2019s central plaza, the streets and walkways are sloped and twisting. Many building foundations have sunk dramatically while others have a visible lean, resulting in cracks in the surrounding pavement. Two of the city\u2019s most iconic structures \u2013 The Palacio de Bellas Artes and the Metropolitan Cathedral (built from the stones of the Aztec temple that once stood there) \u2013 seem to be disappearing into the earth.\r\n\r\nInside the cathedral, Solano-Rojas, a professor of geological engineering at the National Autonomous University of Mexico, points to a glass-encased box connected to the ceiling by a taut wire. At the centre of the nave hangs a heavily-weighted point, which charts a line indicating how the cathedral has shifted unevenly over the centuries, with the worst-impacted section dropping by some 2.5 metres (8.2 feet).\r\n\nAt the centre of the Metropolitan Cathedral\u2019s nave hangs a weight that tracks the cathedral\u2019s motion across the centuries [Nick Hilden/Al Jazeera]\n\r\nMexico City is sinking, as are its greatest monuments. Parts of the city of nearly 9 million people are descending into the earth by as much as 40cm (15 inches) annually \u2013 all driven by a deepening water crisis with roots that go back 500 years, and that reveals itself today in stunning ironies.\r\n\r\nOne of Mexico City\u2019s most renowned attractions, the canals of Xochimilco, with their lush lagoons and colourfully decorated boats, date back to the precolonial lake that once satiated the city\u2019s thirst. Today, its adjacent neighbourhoods have run out of water.\r\n\r\nTo its north is Iztapalapa, one of the city\u2019s most notoriously impoverished, dangerous colonias (neighbourhoods), where the water supply has been inconsistent for years. It frequently slows to a trickle or stops entirely for days and even weeks.\r\n\r\nWhile it is, sadly, not surprising that a disenfranchised district would experience breakdowns in essential services, perhaps more unanticipated are the water shortages in the adjacent region of Coyoacan, an upper-crust neighbourhood best known as the once-home of painting power couple Frida Kahlo and Diego Rivera.\r\n\nA boy carries home buckets filled from barrels of drinking water loaded from tanker trucks in the Mexico City borough of Iztapalapa [Yuri Cortez/AFP]\n\r\nAt the heart of the city\u2019s struggle \u2013 and its sinking \u2013 is its reliance on underground water. As the underground aquifer drains and the ground above it settles, the city sinks deeper and deeper. \u201CThere\u2019s one solution: Stop taking water from underground,\u201D says Solano-Rojas. \u201CBut that\u2019s not going to happen.\u201D\r\n\r\nThe situation in Mexico City shows how the rich and the poor are both ill-prepared for when water supplies run dry \u2013 and money can only go so far.\r\n\nA problem for the ages\n\r\n\u201CI was born with this problem existing,\u201D says Solano-Rojas. \u201CI thought it was normal everywhere, but it\u2019s not.\u201D\r\n\r\nTo understand the \u201Csubsidence\u201D of the city and the water shortage causing it, it is necessary to look back half a millennium. The Aztecs had already erected a civilisation atop and amid the local network of lakes, most notably the capital of Tenochtitlan, which stood on the site of Mexico City\u2019s present-day central district.\r\n\r\nHad the penultimate Aztec ruler Moctezuma\u2019s empire been allowed to continue expanding, it is possible that it would have eventually run into similar water supply issues. But the arrival of the Spanish conquistador Hernan Cortes and his colonial forces disrupted all that \u2013 they levelled Tenochtitlan and built their own city in its place.\r\n\r\n\u201CIt\u2019s a historical problem,\u201D explains Elena Tudela Rivadeneyra, a professor of architecture at the National Autonomous University of Mexico and the co-founder of the Office of Urban Resilience, which develops strategies to help cities weather climate change. \u201CEver since we decided to dry out the lake system that we had here \u2013 and that started [shortly after the Spanish arrived] around 1608 \u2013 we started having a difficult relationship with water.\u201D\r\n\r\nDraining the lakes and building over them created two major issues. First, it diminished the local water supply, requiring the city to import much of its fresh water \u2013 a significant portion of which must be pumped at great expense more than 100 metres (328 feet) up the sierra where the city perches. Second, as the city grew and consumed what water remained, the subsidence began. Problems snowballed from there.\r\n\nThe camera is level but the buildings in the Zocalo are not. Riot police stand at the bottom behind the barriers \u2013 the building to the right is the National Palace where protests are frequent [Nick Hilden/Al Jazeera]\nA sinking city\n\r\nOne of the first things you notice as you land in Mexico City is that the airport runway is unusually bumpy. The increasingly uneven tarmac is a consequence of subsidence.\r\n\r\nListing buildings and uneven roads may be the most obvious impact of the subsidence, but bigger problems lurk out of view.\r\n\r\nA recent study found that the integrity of the metro is progressively compromised \u2013 and there is more, \u201CIt also breaks the pipes,\u201D says Tudela Rivadeneyra.\r\n\r\nWhen Mexico City began modernising its municipal water supply during the 1940s \u2013 an event that Diego Rivera celebrated with the creation of stunning underwater murals you can visit at the C\u00E1rcamo Museum in Chapultepec Park \u2013 its population was only a few million. As that number exploded to the 22.5 million living there today, the water infrastructure not only failed to keep up with the rising demand, but was continually torn apart by subsidence.\r\n\r\nNow, the city is losing some 40 percent of its water due to leaks in broken pipes.\r\n\nThe murals of Deigo Rivera commemorating the construction of the municipal water system at the C\u00E1rcamo Museum in Chapultepec Park in Mexico City [Nick Hilden/Al Jazeera]\n\r\n\u201CThe leakages are quite difficult to deal with,\u201D says Tudela Rivadeneyra. \u201CEven if you replace them with new materials and more elastic and technical and technological solutions, you still have quite an issue.\u201D\r\n\r\nWater infrastructure has become a top consideration among voters in the city\u2019s upcoming mayoral elections, and while candidates have made bold claims about fast fixes, Tudela Rivadeneyra says these are unrealistic. She notes that even if the city had the money for it \u2013 and it does not \u2013 the sheer amount of construction required for a rapid infrastructure rebuild is untenable in a city where people are forced to commute sometimes for hours each day. The increase in the city\u2019s already notorious traffic would grind it to a standstill.\r\n\r\nAs Mexico City runs out of water, for many, the taps are already running dry.\r\n\nThe stones around Bellas Artes are cracking and require frequent repair [Nick Hilden/Al Jazeera]\nDay Zero is already here\n\r\nIn the discussion of the city\u2019s water crisis, the term \u201CDay Zero\u201D is frequently thrown around to describe the presumed date when wells will run dry. Many have set it for late June. But the situation is complicated.\r\n\r\n\u201CI don\u2019t think a Day Zero is going to come,\u201D says Solano-Rojas. \u201CDay Zero has already happened.\u201D\r\n\r\nWhile popular central districts like Condesa and Roma are still relatively unscathed by the situation \u2013 though many of their once-majestic fountains now stand dry \u2013 residents in areas like Iztapalapa and Coyoacan will tell you that the concept of Day Zero is practically meaningless.\r\n\r\n\u201CDay Zero has been here for a lot of people around the whole metropolitan area,\u201D says Tudela Rivadeneyra. \u201CTwenty-five percent of the population does not receive enough water. Technically speaking, 98 percent of the population has the infrastructure to get it, but that doesn\u2019t mean that you open up the tap and there\u2019s water.\u201D\r\n\r\nThe issue extends beyond Mexico City proper.\r\n\r\n\u201CWe don\u2019t have water at home on Saturdays and Sundays,\u201D says Israel, a resident of the nearby town of Toluca. \u201CMonday to Friday, the situation is irregular. There may be a day or two with water and the rest of the weekdays, we only get a very small amount.\u201D\r\n\r\nAnd in Cuernavaca, roughly an hour south of Mexico City, residents have blocked the highway to protest water shortages.\r\n\nStanding at the high rear of the Church of San Francisco, it is clear that the nave floor is sinking [Nick Hilden/Al Jazeera]\n\r\nThe situation has forced the use of stopgap solutions that can only go so far. \u201CPeople can ask for trucks with water in those areas in which the situation is critical,\u201D says Israel. \u201CBut the common solution with some people and local businesses I\u2019ve talked with is that they are paying for private trucks to deliver them water.\u201D\r\n\r\nThese water trucks \u2013 frequently accompanied by armed guards \u2013 are becoming ubiquitous throughout the city. Unsurprisingly, there has been talk about the cartel moving into the private water racket. In Mexico, if something can be commodified, the cartel runs it.\r\n\r\nSo, Day Zero has already come for many in the city, and for those who have not yet experienced it, the issue is more complicated than a date on a calendar.\r\n\r\nThis theoretical timeline refers specifically to the depletion of the Cutzamala Water System, which draws from neighbouring basins that are currently at approximately 30 percent capacity and provide about 30 percent of the city\u2019s water. But that represents less than a third of the water supply: The rest is in the aquifer directly beneath the city.\r\n\r\n\u201CWhat\u2019s really scary is the possibility of Day Zero for the aquifer, because it provides 70 percent of the water we consume,\u201D says Tudela Rivadeneyra. \u201CThat is catastrophe. Right now, people are suffering and it\u2019s not something to take lightly. Thirty percent is like 5 million people \u2013 a quarter of the population of the metropolitan area \u2013 not having enough water\u201D, she says, adding that \u201Cthe aquifer is not replaceable. That is not something you can pull off with water trucks\u201D.\r\n\r\nExperts disagree on how much longer the aquifer can last at current consumption rates, placing the number anywhere between five to 20 years. What is certain is that dramatic action must be taken to avoid a total water disaster.\r\n\r\n\u201CIt\u2019s like a glass where you sip water every day,\u201D says Tudela Rivadeneyra. \u201CEventually, it will run out.\u201D\r\n\nThe iconic Bellas Artes Palace is sinking to its left. Here, the camera is level and flat but the ground is not [Nick Hilden/Al Jazeera]\nThe need for long-term solutions\n\r\nWhile the city scrambles for quick solutions like water rationing, water trucks, individual conservation advocacy and rain-collecting (collection setups have been distributed to many businesses and homes but only recently, Mexico City saw its first drizzle in months), the crisis has been a long time in the making and solutions cannot happen overnight.\r\n\r\n\u201CThere\u2019s not much that can be done in the short term,\u201D Tudela Rivadeneyra admits, \u201Cbecause there\u2019s not enough time or money for it\u201D. She is more hopeful about longer-term solutions but does not \u201Cthink politicians are being practical about them or investing in them enough\u201D.\r\n\r\nMany significant changes must occur, but according to Solano-Rojas, one of the key adjustments is mental. \u201CWe\u2019re using water thinking it\u2019s a renewable resource,\u201D he says. \u201CWe had this big push against single-use plastic like straws but we still have single-use water.\u201D\r\n\r\nIn addition to pumping in tremendous quantities of fresh water, Mexico City also pumps out the vast majority of its used water as sewage to the nearby state of Hidalgo. This pipeline \u2013 a huge infrastructure undertaking called the Tunel Emisor Oriente \u2013 required substantial resources to build, and critics argue that it exacerbates rather than palliates the water crisis by evacuating water from the city rather than retaining it.\r\n\r\n\u201CWe only treat 15 percent of the water,\u201D says Tudela Rivadeneyra. \u201CThat\u2019s a very low percentage, and almost all of the water we use goes to the sewage. So we\u2019re just importing water and exporting all of the problems without dealing with it locally.\u201D\r\n\nSoldiers place a water treatment plant in San Lorenzo Park in Mexico City, on April 11, 2024. The inhabitants of a sector of Mexico City have been affected by the contamination of a water well with an oily substance, in the midst of an extreme drought that affects several parts of the country [Alfredo Estrella/AFP]\n\r\nWith a presidential election looming, the incumbent Andres Manuel Lopez Obrador\u2019s (AMLO) party, Morena, is desperate to appear to be addressing the growing water emergency. One of its primary proposals involves establishing new water wells in the hardest affected areas, but Tudela Rivadeneyra is doubtful, agreeing that in order to construct actual solutions, there must first be a major shift in mindset.\r\n\r\n\u201CIf we do end up getting all of the water wells, bringing water trucks from wherever we can, from other basins \u2013 people will suffer anyways. The demand is too high,\u201D she explains. \u201CWhat we should be focusing on is what to do next and how to change the way we understand water in the city, and the way that water relates to urban development.\u201D\r\n\nPrivatisation and climate change\n\r\nOne oft-cited contributor to the dearth of water is privatisation. Beer, soft drink, paper and chemical manufacturers have significant operations throughout Mexico City and the adjacent State of Mexico, and are granted enormous water concessions. What water regulations they do face are lax in enforcement or circumvented by corruption.\r\n\r\nExperts note that these water rights can be revoked legally and that a precedent has been set by similar actions taken in the past.\r\n\r\n\u201CWhat they should be doing is what they did with the fossil fuel industry,\u201D says Tudela Rivadeneyra. \u201CJust make them go out of the city, because there\u2019s not enough water for them here. They should move to other parts of the country where they have more opportunities to obtain water without drying out the few resources we have.\u201D\r\n\r\nShe\u2019s referring to a plan established by L\u00F3pez Obrador to decentralise the government by relocating Mexico City-based agencies to less populated areas across the country in an effort to ease pollution and infrastructure strain in the megalopolis. While critics have pointed out that this goal was only partially met, it did move the state-owned Pemex petroleum company from its 51-storey tower in the city to the more sparsely populated coast of the state of Campeche, where most of Mexico\u2019s fossil fuels are produced.\r\n\r\nThis sort of decentralisation, emphasises both Solano-Rojas and Tudela Rivadeneyra, is essential to solving the water crisis. Unfortunately, says the latter, relocating water-intensive industry will require prodigious political capital, but there is little willingness to expend it.\r\n\r\nShe notes that while the government has engaged in campaigns to raise awareness for the need for individual responsibility \u2013 shorter showers and the like \u2013 these efforts are not sufficient.\r\n\r\n\u201CBut even if we all did that, it wouldn\u2019t be enough if we still have these concessions,\u201D she says.\r\n\r\nAnd then, of course, there is climate change. On April 15, Mexico City saw its hottest day on record, amid a historic drought.\r\n\r\nRain is essential for renewing the aquifer and leveraging the city\u2019s catchment strategies. In recent years, Mexico City has received less rain but more intense bursts of it. This complicates harvesting because sudden, short-lived eruptions of precipitation require larger gathering surfaces.\r\n\r\nAt the same time, it makes the city more prone to flooding, exacerbated by a lack of open and green spaces that would otherwise allow moisture to seep into the earth.\r\n\r\n\u201CWe should be removing asphalt from parts of the city that don\u2019t really need it, like peripheries,\u201D says Tudela Rivadeneyra.\r\n\r\nAsphalt blocks water seepage, which not only drives flooding but prevents rain from reaching the aquifer. The removal of asphalt is especially important in areas like Iztapalapa, which rests on porous basalt rather than an impervious lake bed like the rest of the city, and may prove vital to replenishing the underground reservoir.\r\n\r\n\u201CWe need to be recharging the aquifer in order to not have a general Day Zero,\u201D Tudela Rivadeneyra emphasises.\r\n\nOn the right of the Metropolitan Cathedral, it is evident that its foundation is sinking [Nick Hilden/Al Jazeera]\nCollective action\n\r\nRecently, it rained in Mexico City for the first time in a long while. This correspondent watched a tiny, very wrinkled elderly woman gaze up at the sky with unguarded delight that verged on relief, her arms spread towards the heavens.\r\n\r\nIf Mexico City is going to overcome this crisis, she and everyone else who lives there \u2013 industrial inhabitants in particular \u2013 will have to change how water is considered.\r\n\r\nAccording to Tudela Rivadeneyra, that means \u201Cfocusing on solutions that have more to do with collectivity. So, instead of having a building just demanding water because it exists, it\u2019s like, what kind of water is it producing? How can we connect it to another building or area that requires that type of water?\u201D\r\n\r\nShe encourages understanding where water originates and where it goeswhy streets become rivers.\r\n\r\n\u201CKnow what\u2019s going on below your feet,\u201D she urges, \u201Cbecause water is very invisible. Making it visible changes the way we relate to it. Dealing with water in different ways that are more circular makes a lot of sense, and it\u2019s not that tough.\u201D\r\n\r\nCan Mexico City achieve the ecosystemic circularity necessary to surmount its water emergency? With the worst yet to come, it seems it is not a matter of can but must.\r\n\nViewed from above, it is difficult to tell, but the iconic Bellas Artes Palace is sinking to its left [Nick Hilden/Al Jazeera]","RSSSummary":"The city faces \u0026#039;Day Zero\u0026#039; as aquifers drain and pipes break. Meanwhile, costly workarounds don\u2019t fix the real problem.","PublishDate":"2024-05-11T12:00:11","IsHeadline":true,"IsPaywall":false,"Summary":"The article explores Mexico City\u0027s severe water crisis and how subsidence has contributed significantly. Jazeera","HasJakeFlag":false},{"Title":"All the Rage in Private Equity: Mortgaging the Fund","Url":"https://www.nytimes.com/2024/05/11/business/dealbook/all-the-rage-in-private-equity-mortgaging-the-fund.html","Text":"Advertisement\r\n\r\nSKIP ADVERTISEMENT\r\n\r\nDealBook Newsletter\r\n\r\nA little-known financial tool was the talk of the Milken Institute\u2019s Global Conference.\r\nThe annual Milken Institute Global Conference in Los Angeles this week.Credit...Frederic J. Brown/Agence France-Presse \u2014 Getty Images\r\nMay 11, 2024, 8:00 a.m. ET\r\n\r\nAt the Milken Institute\u2019s Global Conference this week, a little-known risky financial tool became the subject of a hot debate among Wall Street titans.\r\n\r\nMany private equity firms have quietly begun mortgaging their investment funds, piling leverage upon leverage. In other words, they\u2019re taking out loans against the businesses they\u2019ve already taken out loans to buy.\r\n\r\nAt a time when dealmakers are desperate to raise new cash after the boom of the pandemic era, this mechanism \u2014 known as a net asset value loan \u2014 is allowing them to do it overnight.\r\n\r\nMore P.E. firms are using the tool as they set out to raise their next funds, especially those confronting a hurdle during a slow period for dealmaking: They have yet to return cash to the limited partners they tapped for their last round.\r\n\r\n\u201CWe\u2019re having unprecedented pressure from our L.P.s to send them cash,\u201D Jonathan Sokoloff, the founder Leonard Green, said onstage at the Milken conference. \u201CWe\u2019ll send you cash any way we can.\u201D\r\n\r\nThe big debate at Milken was whether private equity firms that are solving this problem with N.A.V.s are risking their future to buy some time with investors.\r\n\r\nHow N.A.V. loans work. Offered by banks and some smaller private credit-focused lenders, they are backed by the net asset value of select P.E. firms\u2019 investments. They have a higher interest rate than other forms of private equity lending, which appeals to lenders.\r\n\r\nThere is about $150 billion in N.A.V. facilities on the market today, according to the ratings agency S\u0026P Global. It expects that figure to double in the next two years. Investor liquidity is only one use of the loans, which are often invested back into portfolio companies.\r\n\r\nLenders say they offer the loans cautiously. \u201CWhen we come and lend to the portfolio, the fund will be in Year 4 or 5,\u201D Pierre-Antoine de Selancy, a co-founder of the private equity financing firm 17Capital, told DealBook. \u201CWe have a very good source of information.\u201D\r\n\r\nLenders and advisers who work on N.A.V. loans say they are generally structured to minimize risk, with short durations of two or three years and a low loan-to-value ratio, a measure that compares an asset\u2019s estimated value with the size of the loan. Loans against diversified assets can be safer than ones against an individual company because the risk is spread. That can also mean better loan terms.\r\n\r\nBut the danger is leveraging an illiquid asset. The private equity business model relies on taking out debt against each of a fund\u2019s businesses. But N.A.V. loans are most often borrowing against a group of businesses. That diversifies the risk, but it could effectively mean using a good business to help prop up a bad one, while also adding increasingly expensive leverage to an already leveraged fund.\r\n\r\n\u201CIt introduces a greater degree of risk,\u201D Patricia Lynch, who leads the securitization practice at the law firm Ropes \u0026 Gray, told DealBook.\r\n\r\nThe quality of these loans depends in part on a private equity firm\u2019s ability to accurately calculate the value of its businesses (often with the stamp of a third-party appraiser). If the loans sour, it is not fast or easy to sell those assets.\r\n\r\nLimited partners have limited recourse. Many of their agreements with private equity firms were written before N.A.V. loans were in vogue, which means these loans may be technically allowed, if not explicitly. But executives at several large pension funds who spoke to DealBook on the condition of anonymity, because they were not authorized to comment on behalf of their firms, said they had told P.E. firms that they had concerns about using N.A.V. loans for distributions. Others, like Neuberger Berman, take a measured approach.\r\n\r\n\u201CThe general sentiment is: Why are you using them?\u201D Liz Traxler, a managing director at Neuberger Berman, said. \u201CIf you have transparency on the usage, and that aligns with the L.P.s, things are probably going to be very positive.\u201D\r\n\r\nThe worst-case scenario \u2014 that P.E. firms default on their N.A.V. loans \u2014 may be unlikely, but it is an untested risk that could hurt the very investors whom private equity firms are trying to appease in the first place. As Anne-Marie Fink, the chief investment officer of the State of Wisconsin Investment Board, put it onstage at Milken: \u201CIf I get a little bit back now, but you\u2019ve levered the whole fund and I\u2019m cross-collateralized all through a N.A.V. loan, and I eventually lose my money, that\u2019s not a good way for me to get my money back.\u201D \u2014 Lauren Hirsch\r\nIN CASE YOU MISSED IT\r\nTikTok sued to block a law that could force its sale. The company argues that the recently passed law \u2014 which requires the app to split from ByteDance, its Chinese owner, or face a ban \u2014 violates the First Amendment by effectively killing in the United States an app that millions of Americans use to share their views. The heart of the case is lawmakers\u2019 intent to defend the nation from what they and some experts say is a security threat.\r\n\r\nFTX said it planned to repay all its customers. It will base their reimbursement on what they were owed as of November 2022, when the cryptocurrency exchange filed for bankruptcy, plus interest. The customers won\u2019t benefit from the huge jump in crypto prices since then.\r\n\r\nMore drama unfolded around a Paramount deal. If Sony Pictures Entertainment and Apollo Global Management succeed in the $26 billion acquisition they\u2019ve expressed interest in, they plan to break up the media empire, DealBook\u2019s Lauren Hirsch and The New York Times\u2019s Ben Mullin reported. In other potential breakup news, T-Mobile and Verizon are said to be in talks that would divvy up U.S. Cellular, according to The Wall Street Journal.\r\n\r\nU.S. authorities are reportedly examining Tesla\u2019s claims about its Autopilot feature. The inquiry by federal prosecutors centers on whether Elon Musk\u2019s electric carmaker committed securities or wire fraud by suggesting its cars can drive themselves, when its systems require human supervision, according to Reuters. It may again raise the question: Is it fraud, or is it puffery?\r\n\u2018Fun-flation,\u2019 Taylor\u2019s version\r\nEurope has finally gotten in on Taylor Swift\u2019s record-breaking Eras Tour \u2014 and the economic bonanza that seems to come with it.\r\n\r\nThe billion-dollar tour began in Europe on Thursday in Paris\u2019s 40,000-seat La D\u00E9fense arena, before moving on to Stockholm, London, Amsterdam and other major cities through August.\r\n\r\nSwift\u2019s shows appear to have inspired tourists to hit Europe. Americans who missed out last summer at home are taking advantage of a strong dollar, with tickets costing less on the other side of the Atlantic.\r\n\r\nAirbnb rentals are up in the cities hosting concerts. Airbtics, which tracks data on Airbnb rentals, found a sharp uptick in bookings for several European stops on the Eras Tour. In Paris, rental occupancy jumped to nearly 100 percent on Thursday, up from 73 percent a week earlier. Milan, Munich, Vienna and Warsaw saw similar patterns, according to Airbtics. When European tickets went on sale in July, searches for Airbnb rentals in London, Edinburgh, Cardiff and Liverpool during concert dates increased an average 337 percent for show nights, compared with searches for those dates the previous month, according to Airbnb.\r\n\r\nImage\r\nCredit...The New York Times\r\nSome economists expect the Eras Tour to be the first boost for a busy European summer of events. Holger Schmieding, the Berenberg economist who coined the term \u201Cfun-flation\u201D to describe how consumers were splashing out despite high inflation last year, predicts the trend will continue in Europe in 2024. Swift\u2019s tour is one of several big events on the continent, including the UEFA European soccer championship, which starts in Germany next month, and the Summer Olympics, which open in Paris in July.\r\n\r\nHouseholds in Europe may have even more spending firepower than last year. Food and fuel inflation is moderating more rapidly than in the United States, and interest rates could start coming down as soon as next month. \u201CThis summer, we will in Europe have significant further gains in the purchasing power of consumers,\u201D Schmieding told DealBook.\r\nWhat the NFT boom (and bust) says about the dark side of the art market\r\nRemember NFTs? Briefly during the pandemic, the nonfungible tokens generated countless headlines and billions in sales. Now, while other crypto assets are soaring, that market is down to mere millions, and former President Donald Trump is using NFTs to raise campaign funds. But the boom illuminated dark corners of the art market and economy, the Times reporter Zachary Small writes in \u201CToken Supremacy: The Art of Finance, the Finance of Art, and the Great Crypto Crash of 2022.\u201D DealBook spoke with Small about the upcoming book.\r\n\r\nWhat did the emergence of NFTs reveal about the art market?\r\n\r\nThey shed light onto the speculation and laundering that happen in the art market all the time. Sales of NFTs are recorded through the blockchain, so we could see prices in real time as they were changing and deduce what was happening. There was a lot of wash trading, where someone had set up two wallets under different signatures and was trading back and forth to elevate the price of a work until some unsuspecting rube bought into it because they thought it was doing well. Some experts and analysts say that ended up being a significant portion of the market.\r\n\r\nSo should the art market be regulated more like the stock market?\r\n\r\nThe art market is often referred to as the largest unregulated market in the world. You have paintings trading for hundreds of millions of dollars. But the Bank Secrecy Act does not apply, so it\u2019s very easy to use shell companies. Buyers don\u2019t know sellers. Oligarchs have been very successful in using art advisers as patsies and in moving money. But federal regulators have a fundamental difficulty with the art market because it doesn\u2019t seem serious. How do you put a price on art, and who cares? It\u2019s a champagne problem for billionaires.\r\n\r\nNFTs adopted a very similar approach. It\u2019s a genius approach to create things that look ridiculous so regulators feel they don\u2019t really need to step in. From my reporting, that\u2019s a very deliberate strategy on the part of companies and investors to avoid regulation, and it\u2019s worked.\r\n\r\nWhat does the NFT boom tell us about the future?\r\n\r\nWhat\u2019s most urgent to me is that if you want to know how the 20- and 30-year-olds think about the economy, you need to know what they were doing in the NFT and crypto world. I think this acceptance of volatility and speculation as we\u2019ve all lived through the interest rates changing and inflation and all the other economic red flags, it creates a system where speculation and volatility are more accepted. It makes it harder for regulators to safeguard the system.\r\n\r\nThanks for reading! We\u2019ll see you Monday.\r\n\r\nWe\u2019d like your feedback. For further information or assistance related specifically to this message, contact the support team by providing a reference ID mentioned above and referencing \u0022Are you not robot?\u0022 in your inquiry content.","ImageURL":"?","PublisherID":27,"Business":true,"CompaniesMentioned":"","Author":"UNKNOWN AUTHOR","HasJakeFlag":false},{"Title":"Iran and Israel Weren\u2019t Always Enemies","Url":"https://www.nytimes.com/2024/05/08/opinion/iran-israel-middle-east.html","Text":"Advertisement\r\n\r\nSKIP ADVERTISEMENT\r\n\r\nGuest Essay\r\n\r\nHow Iran and Israel Are Unnatural Adversaries\r\nCredit...Raheb Homavandi/Reuters\r\nKarim Sadjadpour\r\n\r\nMr. Sadjadpour is a senior fellow at the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace.\r\n\r\n\u201CHistory is littered,\u201D the British writer and politician Enoch Powell said, \u201Cwith the wars which everybody knew would never happen.\u201D\r\n\r\nA full-blown conflict between the Islamic Republic of Iran and Israel once seemed implausible. But last month, the long-running shadow war between the two nations burst into the open in a series of unprecedented drone and missile strikes, raising the specter of a fight that would contain enough advanced technology, paramilitary forces and mutual acrimony to incinerate large parts of the Middle East, collapse the global economy and entangle the United States and other major powers.\r\n\r\nNow the two sides appear to have hit pause, but for how long? As long as Iran is ruled by an Islamist government that puts its revolutionary ideology before the national interest, the two countries will never know peace, and the Middle East will never know meaningful stability.\r\n\r\nIran and Israel are not natural adversaries. In contrast to other modern conflicts \u2014 between Israel and Palestine, Russia and Ukraine, China and Taiwan \u2014 Iran and Israel have no bilateral land or resource disputes. Their national strengths \u2014 Iran is an energy titan and Israel is a tech innovator \u2014 are more complementary than competitive. The nations also have a historical affinity dating back over 2,500 years, when the Persian King Cyrus the Great freed the Jews from the Babylonian Captivity. Iran was the second Muslim nation, after Turkey, to recognize Israel after its founding in 1948.\r\n\r\nTheir modern animosity is best understood through the lens of ideology, not geopolitics. It began with the rise of Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini, the dogmatic Shiite cleric who led the 1979 revolution that transformed Iran from a U.S.-allied monarchy into an anti-American theocracy. Khomeini\u2019s 1970 treatise \u201CIslamic Government,\u201D which became the basis of the constitution that governs the Islamic Republic, is laced with tirades and threats against \u201Cwretched\u201D and \u201Csatanic\u201D Jews. Then, as now, antisemitism often lurked below the surface of anti-imperialism.\r\n\r\n\u201CWe must protest and make the people aware that the Jews and their foreign backers are opposed to the very foundations of Islam and wish to establish Jewish domination throughout the world,\u201D Khomeini wrote. \u201CSince they are a cunning and resourceful group of people, I fear that \u2014 God forbid \u2014 they may one day achieve their goal and that the apathy shown by some of us may allow a Jew to rule over us one day.\u201D\r\n\r\nIn the same manifesto, Khomeini casually advocates what in modern parlance is best understood as ethnic cleansing. \u201CIslam,\u201D he wrote, \u201Chas rooted out numerous groups that were a source of corruption and harm to human society.\u201D He went on to cite the case of a \u201Ctroublesome\u201D Jewish tribe in Medina that he said was \u201Celiminated\u201D by the Prophet Muhammad.\r\n\r\nVery few of the Iranian revolutionaries and Western progressives who backed Khomeini in 1979 \u2014 some of whom compared him with Mohandas K. Gandhi \u2014 had bothered to scrutinize his vision for Iran. Once in power, he built his newfound theocracy on three ideological pillars: death to America, death to Israel and the subjugation of women.\r\n\r\nOver four decades later, the worldview of Iran\u2019s current rulers has evolved little. Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, Khomeini\u2019s 85-year-old successor and now one of the world\u2019s longest-serving dictators, denounces Zionism in virtually every speech and was one of the few world leaders to publicly praise Hamas\u2019s \u201Cepic\u201D Oct. 7 attack on Israel. \u201CWe will support and assist any nation or any group anywhere,\u201D Ayatollah Khamenei said in 2020, \u201Cwho opposes and fights the Zionist regime.\u201D\r\n\r\nAs Ayatollah Khamenei\u2019s words make plain, the Islamic Republic of Iran is one of the few governments in the world more dedicated to abolishing another nation than advancing its own. \u201CDeath to Israel\u201D is the regime\u2019s rallying cry \u2014 not \u201CLong live Iran.\u201D\r\n\r\nAyatollah Khamenei\u2019s regime has backed this language with action. Iran has spent tens of billions of dollars arming, training and financing proxy militias in five failing nations: Lebanon, Syria, Gaza, Iraq and Yemen. Together these groups constitute its so-called Axis of Resistance against America and Israel. These groups are elbow-deep in corruption and repression in their own societies, including illicit drug dealing and piracy, while pledging that they seek justice for Palestinians.\r\n\r\nHostility toward Israel is a useful tool for predominantly Shiite, Persian Iran to vie for leadership in the predominantly Sunni, Arab Middle East. But it should not be confused with concern for the well-being of Palestinians. In contrast to American, European and Arab governments that fund Palestinian human welfare initiatives, Iran has poured hundreds of millions of dollars into arming and financing Hamas and Palestinian Islamic Jihad. Iran\u2019s goal is not to build a Palestine but to demolish Israel.\r\n\r\nAnd yet as much as the Islamic Republic is committed to its ideology, it is even more committed to staying in power. As the German American philosopher Hannah Arendt once put it, \u201CThe most radical revolutionary will become a conservative on the day after the revolution.\u201D As its careful response to Israel\u2019s recent military strikes on Iran showed, when faced with the possibility of full-blown war or existential economic pressure, Tehran tactically retreats.\r\n\r\nAfter decades of living under an economically failing, socially repressive police state, Iran\u2019s people long ago recognized that the greatest obstacle between themselves and a normal life is their own leadership, not America or Israel. In a 2021 public opinion poll conducted from Europe, only around one-fifth of Iranians approved of their government\u2019s support of Hamas and \u201CDeath to Israel\u201D slogan. Few nations have Iran\u2019s combination of natural resource wealth, human capital, geographic size and ancient history. This enormous gap between Iran\u2019s potential and its citizens\u2019 reality is one reason the country has experienced numerous mass uprisings over the past two decades.\r\n\r\nIran\u2019s Axis of Resistance has empowered right-wing Israeli politicians far more than Palestinians over the past two decades. The threat of a Holocaust-denying Iranian regime with regional and nuclear ambitions has stoked Israeli anxieties, diverted attention from Palestinian suffering and facilitated normalization agreements between Israel and Arab governments equally fearful of Iran. Indeed, Iran and its proxies were such a useful adversary that Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu helped prop up Hamas\u2019s rule in Gaza until the deadly attacks of Oct. 7.\r\n\r\n\u201CThe dream of Israeli leaders,\u201D a retired Israeli general, Amos Yadlin, told me recently, \u201Cis to one day restore normal relations with an Iranian government.\u201D\r\n\r\nThe dream of Iran\u2019s Islamist leaders, on the other hand, is to end Israel\u2019s existence. Israel\u2019s conflict with Iran has been a war of necessity, but Iran\u2019s conflict with Israel has been a war of choice. It won\u2019t be over until Iran has leaders who put Iranians\u2019 interests over Israel\u2019s destruction.\r\n\r\nA version of this article appears in print on , Section\r\n\r\nSR\r\n\r\n, Page\r\n\r\n4\r\n\r\nof the New York edition\r\n\r\nwith the headline:\r\n\r\nIran and Israel Weren\u2019t Always Enemies. This ideological divergence has escalated into armed conflict in recent years through drone strikes that have caused widespread destruction within the Middle East region.\n\n\nSummary 3:\n  \n\nDespite their historical affinity and shared cultural heritage, Iran and Israel find it challenging to resolve conflicts due to deep-rooted animosity rooted primarily in ideology rather than geopolitical differences or resource scarcity. The potential for peace remains uncertain as long as either nation continues down its current path of confrontation without addressing the underlying issues that fuel mistrust between them","ImageURL":"https://static01.nyt.com/images/2024/05/12/opinion/08sadjadpour/08sadjadpour-facebookJumbo.jpg","PublisherID":3,"Business":true,"CompaniesMentioned":"","Author":"Karim Sadjadpour","HasJakeFlag":false},{"Title":"One Black Conservative Continues to Stand Apart","Url":"https://www.nytimes.com/2024/05/08/opinion/glenn-loury-book-conservative.html","Text":"Credit...Kannetha Brown for The New York Times\r\nOpinionPamela Paul\r\n\r\nHe Knows It\u2019s Important to Admit Mistakes. He\u2019s Made Many.\r\n\r\nCredit...Kannetha Brown for The New York Times\r\nMay 8, 2024\r\nGlenn Loury thought maybe the world \u2014 maybe he \u2014 had been wrong about Derek Chauvin, the police officer convicted of murdering George Floyd in 2020. Loury had watched a documentary, \u201CThe Fall of Minneapolis,\u201D that had circulated largely on right-wing social media, arguing that Chauvin had been wrongly convicted, and found himself persuaded. Was it possible, he wondered, that Floyd had actually died of a drug overdose?\r\n\r\nFloyd\u2019s death had ignited protests nationwide and spurred a passionate national debate about racism that often left Loury, a prominent Black conservative, at odds with many other Black intellectuals and with much of the American left.\r\n\r\nHe welcomed the film\u2019s creators, Liz Collin and JC Chaix, as guests on his podcast, \u201CThe Glenn Show,\u201D which has over 100,000 subscribers on YouTube.\r\n\r\nThe blowback was swift and harsh.\r\n\r\n\u201CReally, you\u2019re going to take Chauvin\u2019s side?\u201D friends emailed Loury. Commenters on his newsletter and social media also took issue. Then Radley Balko, an independent journalist, published a long and meticulous critique of the film, calling it \u201Call nonsense.\u201D\r\n\r\n\u201CFrankly, I felt exposed,\u201D Loury told me. We were sitting by the fireplace of his living room on a chilly April afternoon in Providence, R.I., where he is a professor at Brown University. \u201CI felt that my integrity could potentially be called into question.\u201D He needed to \u201Ccome clean.\u201D\r\n\r\n\u201CI pride myself on remaining open to evidence and reason, even if they disconfirm something I had formerly thought to be true,\u201D Loury wrote in a mea culpa for his Substack, calling his error egregious. That weekend, he had Minnesota\u2019s attorney general, Keith Ellison, who oversaw the prosecution of Chauvin in the Floyd case, on his podcast, to hear the other side of the story.\r\n\r\nHow had he made such a mistake?\r\n\r\n\u201CThe real story is I hated what happened in the summer of 2020,\u201D he told me. \u201CI think these moral panics we have around these police killings are over the top and it\u2019s bad for the country.\u201D He had supported the filmmakers, he confessed, because they were attacking people he opposed. \u201CI let that cloud my judgment.\u201D\r\n\r\nThis is far from the first reversal, political or personal, for Loury, 75, one of the most celebrated and reviled Black intellectuals of the past half-century. While public debate has too often devolved into lobbing grenades from entrenched positions, Loury\u2019s tumultuous life, his swings from the right to the left and back again, his remarkable, barrier-busting successes and his considerable frailties and failures, have taught him to always recognize that he could be wrong and to keep an open mind, no matter how vehement his opinions. He outlines this ragged road to wisdom in his remarkably candid memoir, \u201CLate Admissions: Confessions of a Black Conservative.\u201D\r\n\u2018The Enemy Within\u2019\r\nThe name Glenn Loury often appears on lists of prominent conservative Black figures like Thomas Sowell, Clarence Thomas and Shelby Steele. He was a star Ph.D. graduate in economics from M.I.T. and the first Black tenured professor of economics at Harvard. He was a darling of the neoconservative movement and was tapped to be deputy secretary of education during the Reagan administration.\r\n\r\nBut that was before he was charged with assaulting his ex-mistress. Before he was arrested for drug possession. Before he was exposed as both a serial philanderer and a crack addict. He\u2019d left two daughters from his first marriage back in Chicago; he barely acknowledged a son born to a former girlfriend, until the son was fully grown.\r\n\r\nA 1995 New Yorker profile described Loury\u2019s first public downfall thus: \u201CLoury was emerging as exactly the kind of person he had warned Black America to avoid: a violent, irresponsible, drug-using womanizer who put his own pleasure above the demands of his career and the needs of his family.\u201D\r\n\r\nIn recounting all that\u2019s happened since, \u201CLate Admissions\u201D does something that is rare in fiction but almost unheard-of in memoir: It presents both an unlikable and an unreliable narrator.\r\n\r\nIn an unusual introduction, Loury explains that he hopes to build trust with the reader by exposing his obfuscations and prevarications, warding off anything terrible a reader might say about him by saying it all, himself, first. One title he considered for the book, he told me, was \u201CThe Enemy Within.\u201D\r\n\r\nLoury was born in 1948 on the South Side of Chicago. The early childhood scenes in the memoir evoke a close-knit slice of Black working-class life in Park Manor following the Great Migration, a place of honest jobs and not-quite-honest side hustles, to which even his strait-laced Aunt Eloise occasionally turned a blind eye.\r\n\r\nDespite early success in school, by the time Loury was 19, he had dropped out of college, had two children with a high school crush (they eventually married and divorced) and was working at a printing plant.\r\n\r\nIt was only at community college, when a professor recognized his promise and urged him to apply to Northwestern, that Loury turned his life around. After he got a Ph.D. in economics from M.I.T., his rise was meteoric, eventually leading to a dual appointment in economics and Afro-American studies at Harvard in 1982.\r\n\u2018Who Have I Become?\u2019\r\nIn his 1976 dissertation at M.I.T., Loury pioneered a concept of \u201Csocial capital\u201D that became hugely influential. Loury showed that in the labor market, success isn\u2019t predicted purely on the basis of intelligence and skills but also on networks and connections: social capital. These differences, he argued, apart from legal discrimination or racism, often explain racial disparities in the work force.\r\n\r\nIt is a paradox of Loury\u2019s career, then, that he has repeatedly built up and then destroyed his own social capital. His working-class background led him to bristle at some of the assumptions of the Black intelligentsia, particularly the idea that Black people didn\u2019t play a hand in their own circumstances. He resented what he saw as the presumption of a singular liberal opinion among the Black establishment.\r\n\r\nBut at Harvard, Loury, long a critic of affirmative action, couldn\u2019t help but worry he might be there as its beneficiary. The fear that his colleagues doubted his abilities led him to seriously doubt them himself, and he buckled under the pressure, real and imagined. He stopped doing economics research. He hid in his office in the Afro-American studies department.\r\n\r\n\u201CI choked,\u201D he told me. \u201CI wasn\u2019t sure I was good enough.\u201D At the peak of his scholarly performance, he quit the field and took a job at the Harvard Kennedy School where he assumed a busy life of freelance writing, public speaking and conferences.\r\n\r\nImage\r\nA few of the books in Loury\u2019s home office.Credit...Kannetha Brown for The New York Times\r\nImage\r\nLoury working at his desk.Credit...Kannetha Brown for The New York Times\r\nWhen he began publicly criticizing the civil rights movement, he was embraced by the burgeoning neoconservative movement. The intellectual set behind Commentary magazine courted his contributions and he became part of the same circles as Jack Kemp, William Kristol and Norman Podhoretz. He became friendly with Clarence Thomas. He relished their appreciation of his point of view.\r\n\r\nBut in the \u201990s, three popular conservative books on race led him to break with the right: \u201CThe Bell Curve\u201D by Charles Murray and Richard J. Hernstein, which posited a relationship between intelligence and race; \u201CThe End of Racism: Principles for a Multiracial Society,\u201D an incendiary polemic by Dinesh D\u2019Souza; and \u201CAmerica in Black and White: One Nation, Indivisible,\u201D by his friends at Harvard Abigail and Stephan Thernstrom. After he wrote a scathing review of \u201CThe End of Racism\u201D for The Weekly Standard, The Standard published a long rebuttal from D\u2019Souza in the next issue.\r\n\r\nKristol, a former editor of The Weekly Standard, says Loury\u2019s criticism of those books looks good in retrospect. \u201CHe was warier of them that most of us were, to his credit,\u201D Kristol told me. \u201CLoury could have had a pretty easy path to being a famous Black conservative, and he didn\u2019t do that. I kind of respect him for not being one, to be honest.\u201D\r\n\r\nLoury had opposed the politics of the civil rights leadership, rejected affirmative action and thought that behavioral problems in poor Black communities posed a more serious obstacle to progress than discrimination. But in these writers he saw a callousness and even a disdain for Black people.\r\n\r\n\u201CIt made me wonder, who are these people I\u2019m in bed with?\u201D he said to me. \u201CWho am I? Who have I become?\u201D\r\n\u2018I Was Really Broken\u2019\r\nOne through line persisted through all these political rifts. Loury had been living a double life, one that in many ways felt to him more authentic to his urban roots: the life of \u201Cthe player,\u201D a mythic ideal he based largely on his uncle Alfred, a man who fathered 22 children by four women.\r\n\r\nWherever he\u2019d travel, he\u2019d visit the local alleys and bars, playing pickup chess and picking up women, sometimes prostitutes. All the while, he was married to his second wife, Linda, an academic at Tufts, \u201Ctaking this wonderful woman and dragging her through the mud and taking advantage of her, exploiting her fidelity and her patience,\u201D as he put it to me, his voice strained. (Linda died of cancer in 2011.)\r\n\r\nAfter getting arrested in 1987 for domestic abuse of his 23-year-old mistress (the charges were dropped when she stopped cooperating with prosecutors), Loury, then 39, sank into crack addiction, after a prostitute casually introduced him to the drug. Another arrest and two stints in rehab later, Loury entered yet another Black enclave, the Black evangelical church. In the early months of recovery, he was born again.\r\n\r\n\u201CI came into the church on my hands and knees,\u201D he told me. \u201CI mean, I was really broken.\u201D\r\n\r\nIt\u2019s as if Loury repeatedly plays a game of tug of war, with himself and with the wider world. His yearning to belong countered by a suspicion of belonging. Why do you want me here? What purpose am I serving, and is it one I want to carry out?\r\n\r\nThis helps account for his \u201Clurching from left to right to left to right,\u201D the fear of being seen as a token rather than as an \u201Ceconomist who happened to be Black,\u201D and the deeper fear of actually being one.\r\n\r\nIn the late \u201990s and in a decisive and very public move to the left, he started writing about policing and race. He took up mass incarceration \u2014 \u201Cbefore Michelle Alexander!\u201D \u2014 as his main cause and decamped from Harvard to Boston University, where he created the Institute on Race and Social Division. Soon enough, Henry Louis Gates Jr. invited him to give the coveted W.E.B. Du Bois Lectures at Harvard in 2002. For the first time, the Black intellectual establishment opened its doors to him, occasionally with warmth. It felt \u201Cdamn good,\u201D he said.\r\n\r\nAnd then once again that feeling of affirmation started to dissipate.\r\n\r\nWhat bothered him about the left was its evasions, assumptions and methods in addressing issues of racial inequality. What bothered him about the right was that it didn\u2019t seem to share his goal of addressing racial inequality at all.\r\n\r\nThrough all his political shifts, Loury has been consistent in his abiding concern for Black Americans. He believes there are serious problems in Black educational achievement and Black economic, social and health outcomes. The collapse of family, the spread of gangs.\r\n\r\n\u201CThere\u2019s something rotten there, there\u2019s something problematic there, there\u2019s a deep, deep, deep something amiss there,\u201D he said. \u201CAnd I want to say it\u2019s not just them, it\u2019s not just on them, it\u2019s us.\u201D He wants to talk about agency, choice, responsibility.\r\n\r\n\u201CI can\u2019t even look at you in the eye when I\u2019m saying this!\u201D he exclaimed suddenly, interrupting himself. \u201CBecause it\u2019s so hard to say. I mean, it is blaming the victim at some level.\u201D\r\n\r\nI asked Loury: If not affirmative action, if not D.E.I., then what\u2019s the solution? He hesitated, then talked about early childhood education, school reform, investments in mental health, tools to develop the potential of Black families and communities.\r\n\r\nAt heart, he still believes in what he calls \u201Cthe Booker T. Washington-slash-Clarence Thomas\u201D idea that slavery was horrible, but it\u2019s over. Between what he calls the two polar paths to Black progress, W.E.B. DuBois, who emphasized equality and integration with white America, and Washington, who emphasized separatism and self-sufficiency, he falls on the pull-yourself-up-by-your-bootstraps side.\r\n\r\n\u201CWe\u2019re not supposed to talk about out-of-wedlock births. That\u2019s pass\u00E9,\u201D he said. \u201CBut I don\u2019t believe that for a minute!\u201D When 70 to 80 percent of kids are brought up without fathers, he said, \u201CHow\u2019s that not the death knell for the healthy reproduction of social life? How is that not the end? And what I see is excuse making. The artful changing of the subject.\u201D\r\n\r\n\u201CWe need to get busy,\u201D he said. \u201CYou have to stand up.\u201D\r\n\r\nBut he\u2019s still got to check himself. Maybe he\u2019s wrong. His wife of seven years, LaJuan, is strongly committed to her progressive beliefs. Their marriage, he said, has \u201Chad far-reaching implications for my own intellectual life.\u201D Together they listen to the left-wing podcasts she favors: \u201CThe Jimmy Dore Show,\u201D \u201CMax Blumenthal,\u201D \u201CDue Dissidence.\u201D Not only is he exposed to different ideas, but out of his respect for his wife, he has to \u201Cself-interrogate a bit.\u201D\r\n\u2018I Am a Fallen Man\u2019\r\nLoury remains a hugely popular economics professor at Brown, where he has taught largely progressive students since 2005. His classes are always oversubscribed, especially now that he has announced plans to retire next year. In recent years he has taught a class on free inquiry in the modern world, which he developed with an undergrad who told him he was sick of people not saying what they really thought.\r\n\r\n\u201CIt\u2019s maybe the most gratifying teaching experience I\u2019ve had in my career,\u201D he told me. \u201CBecause we tackle the cancel-culture-political-correctness conundrum.\u201D\r\n\r\nLast semester, Loury co-taught a class on race, crime and justice in America. Former students told me they relish the open debate they find in his classroom. \u201CAt times it could get a little heated,\u201D Ayla Kim, a junior, said. \u201CBut it generated a lot of thought. I felt more informed on particular issues hearing multiple sides.\u201D\r\n\r\nHenry Mass, a senior, told me: \u201CIt\u2019s pretty unique and refreshing to get to hear a deviation from the standard opinion in college, it\u2019s sad to say. You\u2019re meant to nod your head and conform in other classes. But this was really cool. We were allowed to argue on a number of hot-button issues, whether it was police abolition or affirmative action.\u201D The students I spoke with all loved the class.\r\n\r\nLoury hopes to continue teaching after retirement, even without pay. He\u2019d like to take up piano. He plans to continue his podcast, having just constructed a new studio in his basement. These projects excite him in a way contemporary politics do not. Loury still doesn\u2019t know whom he\u2019ll vote for this fall, but he knows he won\u2019t vote for President Biden; he says he\u2019ll probably abstain or vote for his friend Cornel West. That\u2019s where his free-market conservatism comes in and his distrust of \u201Cthe liberal Democratic cognoscenti,\u201D which he finds patronizing. \u201CMuch of the D.E.I. initiative backed by Biden is little more than pandering with irrelevant concessions to an elite wing of the Black Democratic establishment,\u201D he explained.\r\n\r\n\u201CI\u2019m terrified for the future of this country,\u201D he told me. \u201CNobody trusts anybody anymore. I fear that seeds of dissension have been sown that will bear a bitter fruit down the line, so I\u2019m finding it hard to be optimistic.\u201D\r\n\r\nHe also worries about the publication of \u201CLate Admissions,\u201D which comes out on Tuesday. He knows some people will be \u201Cgunning\u201D for him because they find his politics despicable; that\u2019s not what bothers him.\r\n\r\nWhat he does fear is that students and friends will form negative opinions of him. His two adult daughters by his first wife have read the book. \u201CAnd they are not happy campers,\u201D he said slowly. A close friend read it and said to Loury, \u201CI don\u2019t know if I like that guy,\u201D to which Loury responded, \u201CI don\u2019t know if I like him either.\u201D\r\n\r\n\u201CI am a fallen man,\u201D he told me, repeating a phrase that appears near the end of the book. \u201CI cannot defeat the enemy within, not entirely.\u201D\r\n\r\nPamela Paul is an Opinion columnist at The Times, writing about culture, politics, ideas and the way we live now.\r\n\r\nA version of this article appears in print on , Section\r\n\r\nSR\r\n\r\n, Page\r\n\r\n12\r\n\r\nof the New York edition\r\n\r\nwith the headline:\r\n\r\nOne Black Conservative Continues to Stand Apart. The mesmerizing glow of Kharkiv in northeast Ukraine further added to this captivating display.\n\nThe Northern Lights offer a breathtaking glimpse into the vastness of space, reminding us that even amidst technological advancements, nature\u0027s wonders still hold their power and inspire awe among those who witness them firsthand","ImageURL":"https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/news/1024/branded_news/AC43/production/_133299044_490f351d5bd04c8aa40f84dace77d168e6b43a3c.jpg","PublisherID":2,"Business":true,"CompaniesMentioned":"","Author":"By Natasha Preskey","HasJakeFlag":false},{"Title":"On Mother\u2019s Day, Here Are 2 Novels That Get Babies Right","Url":"https://www.nytimes.com/2024/05/11/books/read-like-wind-recommendations-babies-in-fiction.html","Text":"Advertisement\r\n\r\nSKIP ADVERTISEMENT\r\n\r\nImage\r\nCredit...Monika Chatterton/Connected Archives x Kintzing\r\nDear readers,\r\n\r\nFor the past few months I\u2019ve been on a scavenger hunt. Where are the fully realized babies in fiction? I wasn\u2019t after infants who are incidental to the plot; I wanted babies whose babyhood was essential to the story.\r\n\r\nI shouldn\u2019t be surprised by this itch. It has been the year of the baby for my loved ones. Blink, and a friend\u2019s little bundle of semi-consciousness has grown to the size of a koala. What\u2019s going on in there, little guy?\r\n\r\nLook, babies freak me out. Whenever I\u2019m around them I worry about doing something that will forever alter their lives, like holding a bottle at the wrong angle or making curse words sound cool. But I don\u2019t see them exiting my life any time soon, and this is an irrational, unbiological fear that I\u2019d like to overcome. Enter literary exposure therapy.\r\n\r\nMy holy grail? A bouncing, gurgling Chekhov\u2019s gun. If a baby appears in the first act, I expect it to start crawling by the last. I\u2019m pleased to share the results of my spelunking: a can-do, women-run novel from Barbara Kingsolver and a deeply weird, overlooked British story that puts a baby\u2019s existence into grotesquely brilliant prose. The children are our future; teach them well and let them lead the way.\r\n\r\n\u2014Joumana\r\n\u201CThe Bean Trees,\u201D by Barbara Kingsolver\r\nFiction, 1988\r\n\r\nOf course Barbara Kingsolver, She Who Treats All Her Characters With Dignity, has a memorable baby in her universe. She unfurls the same expansive humanity across each of her books, including this, her debut.\r\n\r\nMeet Taylor Greer, daughter of Pittman County, Ky. More important, she\u2019s the daughter of a single mother who believed Taylor hung the moon and \u201Cplugged in all the stars.\u201D Taylor dreams of more for herself than what her small hometown could offer \u2014 a life of babies and tobacco farms and not much else. When she has enough saved to buy a \u201955 Volkswagen (with no windows, no back seat and no starter, mind you), she heads West.\r\n\r\nAfter a verbal tussle with a cowboy in Oklahoma \u2014 a careless pass of a diner ketchup bottle sloshes out a few cents\u2019 worth of coffee from Taylor\u2019s mug, a scene that will be achingly familiar to anyone who\u2019s robbed Peter to pay Paul \u2014 a Native woman gives Taylor a young child and disappears. The woman who left Kentucky to avoid motherhood now has a mute little girl she knows nothing about as her charge.\r\n\r\nShe names her Turtle, on account of how tightly the child clings to her. \u201CI think it would have been easier to separate me from my hair,\u201D she thinks. Appropriately, Turtle is slow to show herself, and for heartbreaking reason.\r\n\r\nTaylor\u2019s worldliness dilates quickly once she and Turtle reach Tucson, their eventual home. She has big Erin Brockovich energy, and a sense of humor: Scanning rental listings in the local paper, \u201CI began to suspect that sharing harmonious space with an insightful Virgo might require even greater credentials than being a licensed phlebotomist in the state of Arizona.\u201D\r\n\r\nSome of Taylor\u2019s wit and mettle recede as the story aims for a bigger message. There\u2019s a secondary plot involving migrants seeking a sanctuary of their own, just as mother and daughter ease into their adopted city. But that unexpected maternal love is a constant, and it\u2019s a pleasure that Turtle is much more than a foil to Taylor or the catalyst for Taylor\u2019s coming-of-age; she\u2019s a loving and resilient child, and memorable in her own right.\r\n\r\nRead if you like: The movie \u201CMask,\u201D heritage seed catalogs, \u201C9 to 5\u201D\r\nAvailable from: The library, probably your mom\u2019s bookshelf, a well-stocked motel lobby\r\n\u201CLord Jim at Home,\u201D by Dinah Brooke\r\nFiction, 1973 (reissued 2023)\r\n\r\nWhat a startling, disorienting book. You read it in a stupor, much as babies go through their earliest days. I\u2019m glad the author wrote it before retreating to an ashram in Maharashtra; I loved it.\r\n\r\nWe are in Cornwall between world wars. Nestled in a posh cliffside home are the King, the Queen and their little Prince, a mewling infant whom we get to know through his senses.\r\n\r\n\u201CThe Prince lies in his mother\u2019s lap. He is good. The sun is balmy on his face. The fears of the dark cupboard have shrunk to the size of an old man wrapped in a dark fringed rug.\u201D (Imagine if babies had this sort of language available to them!)\r\n\r\nBut this is no idyll. The Prince lives for moments with his mother, away from his rigid, starchy nurse, when he is fed \u201Ckisses and licks of sugar.\u201D Here comes the melodrama \u2014 \u201Cthe exquisite pain, torn away from this tender sweetness, fingers clutching, body arched, screams of despair. Even a rat would have learned that a broken string of pearls and knocked over teacup meant that next day there would be no love, no sugar. The Prince learns in the end, but a rat would have learned sooner.\u201D\r\n\r\nThese early ruptures are nauseating to read, however modish such tactics of deprivation and discipline were at the time. And yet they\u2019re essential to the story, which follows the boy to school, the Navy and beyond. Privilege and torture create the firmament of his selfhood. We cannot understand this individual \u2014 and his ultimate acts of horror \u2014 without having peered down at him from the bars of his crib.\r\n\r\nYou don\u2019t need to have read Joseph Conrad\u2019s 1900 novel \u201CLord Jim\u201D to appreciate this book, but it\u2019s a useful referent. (Quickly, in case you\u2019ve lost your seminar notes: \u201CLord Jim\u201D follows a sailor who makes a cowardly decision at sea, and tries to outrun the consequences; the Book Review called it a \u201Cstudy of a soul.\u201D)\r\n\r\nThis, too, is an explicit call to judge an ambiguous, passive, coolly voided man, resulting in a soup-to-nuts character study that is less \u201CFrank Sinatra Has a Cold\u201D than \u201CRobert Mugabe Has a Migraine.\u201D\r\n\r\nRead if you like: voir dire, Shelley Duvall\u2019s Faerie Tale Theatre, pedagogical debates, Mother\u2019s wedding china\r\nAvailable from: Luckily for us, McNally Editions released this for the first time in the United States last year, so most major book retailers will carry it; otherwise, Anglophiles might be peddling first editions wherever used books are sold\r\nWhy don\u2019t you \u2026\r\nTake heed of Alice McDermott\u2019s writing wisdom, conveniently collected in \u201CWhat About the Baby?\u201D\r\n\r\nAcquaint yourself with some of my favorite children in recent fiction, courtesy of Camille Bordas?\r\n\r\nTour a school to send your baby to, run by Donald Barthelme?\r\n\r\nThank you for being a subscriber\r\n\r\nPlunge further into books at The New York Times or our reading recommendations.\r\n\r\nIf you\u2019re enjoying what you\u2019re reading, please consider recommending it to others. They can sign up here. Browse all of our subscriber-only newsletters here.\r\n\r\nFriendly reminder: check your local library for books! By delivering accurate information responsibly without bias or sensationalism the newspaper strives to maintain its position as a trusted source for informed decision-making among readers seeking insights into global affairs and current events around the world","ImageURL":"?","PublisherID":13,"Business":true,"CompaniesMentioned":"BP.L (BP),WIZZ.L (Wizz Air),Construction.L (LT),","Author":"UNKNOWN AUTHOR","HasJakeFlag":false},{"Title":"Dutch Contestant Disqualified From Eurovision Song Contest Hours Before Final","Url":"https://time.com/6977117/eurovision-song-contest-2024-dutch-contestant-joost-klein-disqualified/","Text":"MALMO, Sweden \u2014 It\u2019s time for many people to don sequins and spangles \u2014 and for others to pick up protest banners and Palestinian flags \u2014 for Saturday\u2019s final of the 68th Eurovision Song Contest.\r\n\r\nThe competition that pits nations against one another for pop music glory is reaching its conclusion in the Swedish city of Malmo, with Croatia and Switzerland among those tipped to take the trophy, and Israel at the center of a political storm.\r\n\r\nHours before the final, Dutch contestant Joost Klein was dramatically booted out by organizers over a backstage incident. He had failed to perform at two dress rehearsals on Friday, and contest organizer the European Broadcasting Union said it was investigating an \u201Cincident.\u201D\r\n\r\nThe EBU said Swedish police were investigating \u201Ca complaint made by a female member of the production crew\u201D and it would not be appropriate for Klein to participate while the legal process was underway.\r\n\r\nThough rumors had been flying the incident was connected to Israel\u0027s delegation, organizers said the incident \u201Cdid not involve any other performer or delegation member.\u201D\r\n\r\nThough the contest\u2019s motto is \u201Cunited by music,\u201D this year\u2019s event has attracted large protests from Palestinians and their supporters, who say Israel should be excluded because of its conduct of the war against Hamas.\r\n\r\nThousands of people are expected to march for the second time this week through Sweden\u2019s third-largest city, which has a large Muslim population, to demand a boycott of Israel and a cease-fire in the seven-month war. In Finland, a group of about 40 protesters stormed the headquarters of public broadcaster YLE on Saturday morning, demanding it withdraw from the song contest because of Israel\u0027s participation.\r\n\r\nSeveral miles (kilometers) from central Malmo at the Malmo Arena, 25 acts \u2014 narrowed from 37 entrants by two semi-final runoffs \u2014 are due to perform three-minute songs in front of a live audience of thousands and an estimated 180 million viewers around the world.\r\n\r\nIt all makes for a messy climax to an event that draws both adoration and derision with its campy, kitschy ethos and passion for pop.\r\n\r\nDean Vuletic, an expert on the history of the contest, says that despite this year\u0027s divisions, \u201Cthere is no other cultural event which brings Europeans together quite like Eurovision does.\u201D\r\n\r\n\u201CJust this moment where everyone is watching the same television show, which is being broadcast live across 37 countries \u2014 that\u2019s something very special.\u201D\r\n\r\nThis year\u2019s entries range from emotional to eccentric. They include the goofy 1990s nostalgia of Finland\u2019s Windows95man, who emerges from a giant onstage egg wearing very little clothing. Ireland\u2019s Bambie Thug summons witchy spirits onstage and has brought a scream coach to Malmo, while Spain\u2019s Nebulossa boldly reclaims a term used as a slur on women in \u201CZorra.\u201D\r\n\r\nThe favorites include Swiss singer Nemo \u2014 who would be the first nonbinary Eurovision winner if their operatic song \u201CThe Code\u201D tops the voting \u2014 and Croatia\u2019s Baby Lasagna. His song \u201CRim Tim Tagi Dim\u201D is a rollicking rock number that tackles the issue of young Croatians leaving the country in search of a better life.\r\n\r\nVuletic says that despite the contest\u2019s reputation for disposable bubblegum pop, Eurovision often tackles \u201Cpolitical and social issues such as feminism, European integration, gender identity.\u201D\r\n\r\n\u201CAnd I think they\u2019re the very interesting songs to look out for, especially because they\u2019re the most highly ranked by the bookies,\u201D he said.\r\n\r\nSometimes, though, songs run afoul of the contest\u2019s ban on openly \u201Cpolitical\u201D statements. Eurovision organizers told Israel to change the original title of its song, \u201COctober Rain\u201D \u2014 an apparent reference to the Oct. 7 Hamas attack that killed about 1,200 Israelis and triggered the Gaza war.\r\n\r\nIsraeli singer Eden Golan has shot up the odds since performing the power ballad, now titled \u201CHurricane,\u201D in Thursday\u2019s semifinal. Golan faced some booing at dress rehearsals, but was voted into the final by viewers around the world.\r\n\r\nIsraeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu praised 20-year-old Golan for performing despite \u201Ccontending with an ugly wave of anti-Semitism.\u201D\r\n\r\nProtesters argue that Israel should not be allowed to take part amid a war that has killed almost 35,000 Palestinians.\r\n\r\n\u201CI don\u2019t think they should be a part of it at all because they are committing crimes against humanity,\u201D said local resident Lorenzo Mayr, who attended a demonstration on Thursday.\r\n\r\nThe competing musicians are feeling the pressure, inundated with messages and abuse on social media and unable to speak out because of the contest rules.
